  15. When I first opened the packaging, I thought the head was flimsy. Wrong. It was just different from my previous Norelco. It looks modern and adjusts to curves easily. I have owned other Norelco Shavers and, though I loved the convience and the smooth shave, I often turned it off accidently while shaving. Evidently, the on/off switch was positioned for the places men shave. This razor seldom turns off and works well in my hand. The shaver charged quickly. Interestingly, the razor must be in the holder to recharge. This means an extra thing to carry when traveling. I haven't yet cleaned it but it seems to require a special cleaning device that did not come with it. Overall, good product.
  16. Wow, this is a nice shaver. It provides a close shave and it sleek and modern looking. Not that the look is THAT important, but it kind of is in marketing the product. The blades are easy to clean too. The only thing that I could see improved on this shaver is that when it is charging it tends to lean as the base is not heavy enough to support the weight of the dangling cord. You will need to prop it against the wall to steady it. Not really that big of a deal though.
  17. I have to admit before I start that I mistakenly thought that this razor was to shave my legs. I didn't realize that it was a beard and hair trimmer until I received it in the mail. Because of this, I felt the need to use the Philips Norelco 1150x/40 SensoTouch 2d Electric Shaver on my husband's beard. I didn't think using it on my legs, even if it would have worked, would have been suffice for the information I need for this review. The charging time is optimal. Not too long to wait and the razor comes alive. I have a good bit of fun shaving my husbands face just because the shaving element was so sharp and it totally rocked as a close shave. Then I used the hair trimmer and voila! I fell in love with this razor! My husband's face was soft with little or no stubble. I tested his face once he returned from work and his beard had grown very little during the day. This is an awesome product that men definitely need in their bathrooms to use with grooming. Natalie S.
  18. it is very good and nice shoping at amazon
  19. This is an experiment as I am used to a tri-blade razor. The price of blades has gone out of sight. If this animal can replace 80 or so blades before having to replace the heads, I will be ahead of the game.<br /><br />The packaging is the old timing cut your hand before you open type that most manufacturers have abandoned. However the system came with a small how-to maintain the razor manual. It was easy to plug in the stand and wait for the razor to charge.<br /><br />I had to use it over the same surface several times but eventually it did its job. It was easy to clean with just a quick rinse as long as you can keep the cats face out of it. It sort of looks like an electronic lotus in its stand.<br /><br />I have not tried any pre-shave lotion, and may never, but I am looking for one that is not smelly.<br /><br />Mean time I have not calculated the amount of electricity this uses. I will be unplugging the stand with charging is complete.<br /><br />This system has a two year warranty but it is so inexpensive that it would be easier to toss it if anything should happen.

  22. Since I am a senior citizen, I have used many different wet/dry shavers in my lifetime. This senso touch tilts and moves to the countours of the face for the smoothest and most comfortable shave ever.
  23. Have been using this shaver for over a month now - haven't had to charge it yet! The trimmer isn't great, but other than that I am very pleased.

  25. The shaver does a decent job on the obvious places (the cheeks, around the jawline, etc.), but it is HORRIBLE around the neck. I've tried moving my neck in all sorts of ways, gone over the trouble areas multiple times, and it still leaves batches of hairs. The worst spot is around the adam's apple, where I actually got a nasty in-grown hair because of the way I had to go about trying to shave the hair there. That's why I'm returning this item.<br /><br />So long story short, if your neck hair grows fairly low, this shaver won't get it at all. Maybe go with one of the 3D models that might change their angle to get that area better, a foil shaver, or the trusty blade.
  26. I bought it last week as my father's gift. looks good,but I never try. Why the price goes up, I bought it as $84,but it's $90 now... I intend to buy another for myself...
  27. For the past 8 months I had been using a [[ASIN:B001AMRQ2W Philips Norelco Speed 8240 Men's Shaving System]] but recently forgot it at a family members house and found myself in need of a temporary razor solution. The 8240 had been my first rotary razor experience and I had been very pleased with it, so I decided I would give this razor a try as I wanted to see what the wet shaving experience was all about. For dry shaving this razor is pretty good. The quality of the shave seems just as good as the 8240, although the 8240 was the \\"Speed\\" model and I do think provided for a quicker shave. For wet shaving I was really impressed with this razor. I used it with Edge shave gel and it was an absolutely pleasant shaving experience. The razor glided very well and gave me the smoothest shave I have ever had with an electric razor. The biggest benefit of this to me though is that I can shave when my face is anything other than perfectly dry. All my previous dry razors would catch and stick and my skin was even the slighest bit most. But with this razor if my skin is wet( like after a shower) and I can just use some shave gel and get a perfect shave. My other favorite features about this razor and the 8240 is how easy they are to clean. Either razor you can easily pop the cutting heads off of and then just run it under some water to clean. Only takes a couple seconds and does a great job keeping it clean.
  28. This Philips Norelco 1150x/40 is in my opinion one of the best rotary wet shavers I have used. I have been using Norelco rotaries for the past 25 years or so, but this one is the best. I even tried a foil shaver from a competetor but this Norelco is way better. I can not comment on it as a dry shaver. The wet shave is so comfortable that I wouldn't even think of using it as a dry shaver. I would also would like to say I have no shaving irriatation and the battery charge stays for over two weeks.   29.   30. I had been using a combo of Braun and regular razor shave when the Braun shave kept whiskers too long. I bought this Norelco since a friend of mine had been using one. Razors have changed a lot in 3 years. This cheaper razor runs circles around my Arcitec. I would finish a shave with the old razor, and invariably there would still be 20-30 straggler hairs that I would have to go over a second/third time to catch them. (And yes, I clean my razor's and change the heads periodically). With this new razor, I notice maybe 5 stragglers, and they will sweep up on my second pass usually, making this razor easily 5 minutes faster than using my old Arcitec. I think the biggest difference though between this razor and my old Arcitec is that my face feels SOOOO smooth after using the 1150x! It's almost as if the razor head/foils cut the hair even deeper than the old Arcitec did... and I'm not complaining! Great Job Norelco, this one will be a great Christmas present for dads this year!

  71. Ok so, i was an owner of Philips norelco 8000 series with the triple track system and a cleaning station and everything. That gave me a smooth shave and was very happy with it. I must say that the initial 2 weeks were horrible with weird cuts on my face that left me with irritation. But later it got good.... really good. A week ago i saw the new sensotouch, which was 50 dollars cheaper and water proof, so i returned the 8000 series and bought this one. I must say that the triple track system of the 8000 series and the single track of the 1150 has made no difference in my shaving experience. Its cheaper and water proof, which i must say feels so much closer to the traditional shaving experience with a shaving gel and everything. It shaves wonderfully around the neck region, with minimal irritation. Since i have a thick growth, i prefer clean shaving everyday and this is where philips wins hands down. I could never shave everyday with a blade, which would leave me with cuts all over my face. Over all i am very happy with my purchase and recommend it to everyone who is considering this shaver. Btw, when the manual recommends you to use it for couple of weeks to get used to the shaver, they are not kidding. Do give it time before your skin adjusts and while you try to figure out the right pressure and shaving motions that suits your face. Ciao.

  75. Shaving has always been an issue with my face and I loathed doing it. Blade shaving almost always resulted a nick or cut that would take forever to stop bleeding as well as some razor burn. I had used a single foil electric shaver a couple years ago that wasn't anything to write home about. I mostly resolved to using a beard trimmer, but that would always be a painful scratching experience. So after years of this I decided to find myself a good rotary shaver. I first puchased a Norelco 7340XL razor and went to work with it. It most certainly did get a much nicer cleaner shave, almost as clean a blade, but I was left with a shredded up neck line and bad irration. I gave it a week until I decided to find a preshave. I've used Remington's Face Saver before and found it worked well, but stores around here no longer carry it. So I figured some Lectric Shave, or Afta would do the trick but....the Lectric Shave smelled like pure alcohol, and the Afta left me smelling like an old man, like something my grandpaw wears. Either was a no go, so I decided to bite the bullet and return the 7340XL and find a much better shaver. I really wanted something I could use in the shower and at the price point I was looking at(I couldn't see myself paying for a Jet Clean that does something I could do myself, plus I don't have the counter space)I narrowed it down to the 1150x or the Nivea For Men Shaver. I choose the 1150x because the Nivea cartridges would get pricey over time, and had read that without it it can lead to irritation. First off, this is a really nice razor. I really like the design of it and actually prefer that the heads interchange for shaving and trimming. The popout trimmer of the 7340XL just felt akward. Upon first use the 1150x gave me as close as a blade shave, with no nicks, no cuts, no burn and no irritation,,,SUCCESS!!!! I then decided to get some foam and shave in the shower with it and without a doubt, it's the best shave I have found yet. I've found theperfect shave...for me!!!!

  79. i bought this shaver because my braun 5 series stop charging completely. i have owned 2 braun, 1 panasonic, and 1 philips before this one, and this is the best one that i have ever owned even thought it wasn't the most expensive one. it gives a very close shave and i can shave in the shower. I love the look, and the design. its charging time is only 1 hour and it lasts me almost 3 weeks before i have to charge it again.( i shave once every three days). at first, i use this with shaving cream, but one time i used it with Nivea face wash for men, and to my surprise....it works just as well...so now, i don't even buy shaving cream any more....just shave in the shower and wash my face right after...get 2 things done at once. another thing that i like about this shaver is that you can't really press hard against your skin....its weird how they designed it....no matter how hard i press it against my face or neck, i just can't feel the pressure and yet it shaves clean...its a good thing that you can't press hard against your skin, because with my previous shaver, i tend to press hard and get some skin burn after the shave....so this product completely eliminated that problem for me....cleaning is so easy, after the shave, just pop open the blade cover and run both parts under water...and its as clean as the first time you use it....so i don't suggest people to buy the more expensive model of this product( i think its senso touch 3D or something like that) because there is no need. this product's performance exceeds my expectation and its the best bang for the buck.
  80. The new Philips Norelco 1150x is one slick shaving device that looks right out of Star Trek. While keeping the original traditional 3 circular heads design, it improves radically on many important points. First, the new body: it's made of a cool looking metallic material that integrates buttons and lights in a continuous surface, so it's very easy to wipe clean. The lights appear behind transparent areas of the surface. Then, the convenience of the design: top notch. First, because the shaving heads are mounted on a deported piece with a narrow neck, it's very easy to see what you're doing. I never thought it was important, but I found out how much I had been missing. Also, unlike older designs with a pop-up trimmer of limited usability due to its lack of clearance, on this shaver the trimmer just plugs into the top of the body as a replacement to the shaving heads, so the angle, clearance and visibility are perfect. Both wet and dry shaving are supported; cleaning and taking apart the shaving head is very easy, just rinse under the tap and air dry. The shaving accuracy is excellent, although I don't see it as a marked improvement over my previous Philips/Norelco (which I was perfectly satisfied with) Charging is fast (full charge in an hour, but you can use the shaver within minutes of charging) The 1150x/40 is also very quiet for an electric shaver. The box contains the shaver body, shaving head, trimmer attachment, cleaning brush, brush head cover, charging stand and world-capable charging adapter (110-240V). The charger is considerably smaller than the ones Philips/Norelco used to bundle, which is an excellent improvement especially for travelers. There were a couple of points where I thought the design fell a little short, but they're small enough that I don't think it would be fair to ding the rating of this otherwise excellent shaver by a star: - The power adapter only connects to the stand, not the shaver; the only way you can charge the shaver is by using the charging stand, which does not fold up. That makes this shaver unnecessarily inconvenient to pack. Obviously, removing the power connector from the shaver's body improves its water resistance, but still, it's unfortunate. - Although the trimmer is considerably more useful than the built-in trimmer of previous models, it's also another small, easy to lose part. It would have been nice to have a place to store it on the charging stand. - No carry case. Still, considering its excellent performance and convenience, I think this shaver deserves 5 stars. Definitely one of the best I've used, and its great head clearance and trimmer make it perfect to maintain a nice trimmed beard. Highly recommended.
  81. This is my first electric razor ever. Razors are expensive so I figured I would invest instead of spend. It's a pretty fairly priced razor and it gets the job done. My face definitely took about a month to adjust to it but now it's much better. I do have to spend an extra minute in a few places that are hard to reach for the blades around my neck, but it's still faster and easier than a manual razor. If you're looking to upgrade from a cheapo unit I would go even higher than this one and spend a few extra bucks. If you're starting out like I was then I would recommend this unit, I plan on keeping it for years to come.
  82. The [[ASIN:B003V360NY Philips Norelco 1150x/40 SensoTouch 2d Electric Shaver, Metallic Blue]] is a good electric razor for those looking to buy a SensoTouch model. For those who don't need the better detail trimmer, the [[ASIN:B001AJ6YS2 Philips Norelco 7310XL Men's Shaving System]] offers a decent shave for less. The trade-offs are the better features and longer battery life. The 1150 operates faster and quieter than the 7310, and it has a better trimmer than either the 7310 or the 1250.<br /><br />The 1150 is the best value you can get in the SensoTouch line. Like the [[ASIN:B003V37Z9W Philips Norelco 1250cc/42 SensoTouch 3d]] it is best designed for daily use of shorter facial hair. If you let your hairs get too long it requires too many passes to get them all. It doesn't take long to produce noticeable neck irritation. The discomfort did subside with longer term use. However, there was always some discomfort when shaving the neck area.<br /><br />The 1150x doesn't include the 3D heads of the 1250x and the cleaning station of the 1250cc. The battery also lasts for 40 minutes instead of 60. But for half the investment, this unit is worth consideration despite the missing features.<br /><br />PROS:<br />++ Good performance for an electric shaver<br />++ Best for daily shaving of shorter facial hair<br />++ The attachment trimmer works better than the 1250's pop-up trimmer<br />++ Smooth and quiet operation compared to most electric razors<br />++ Charging is quick<br />++ Can be used wet or dry, and with or without shaving cream or gel<br />++ The shaving heads can be cleaned under water<br />++ The included soft case makes it easy to transport<br />++ The charging base is compact and has suction cups for mounting<br />++ The device is attractive and sleek<br />++ Comprehensive manual covers a lot, including usage, maintenance and parts replacement<br /><br />CONS:<br />-- Leaves longer hairs behind when shaving<br />-- Alternatives like the 7310 still offer a better value for most of the same features<br />-- The trimmer requires manual attachment, though it's worth it since it functions better than the pop-up on the 1250<br />-- The battery lasts less time than all other SensoTouch models<br />-- Recommended annual blade replacements add significant cost<br />-- There is no indicator for blade replacement or cleaning<br />-- The battery indicator includes 2 stages instead of the 5 on the 1250<br />-- The battery is not user-replaceable and will limit the unit's life<br />-- Does not include the jet cleaning system<br />-- The soft pouch is not as nice as the carrying case included with other models<br /><br />CONCLUSION<br /><br />For most users, lower end models like the 7310 will work sufficiently well. The 1150 is a compromise, but unless you really need the detail trimmer give the entry level units a try first.<br /><br />Those who want the Jet Clean system should try the 1250, as long as they are willing to pay the premium and don't mind the hassle and expense of changing the fluid.<br /><br />I would still recommend this over the 1250. For a much more reasonable investment of time and funds, you can have an almost equivalent shaving experience.<br /><br />Enjoy.al attachment, though it's worth it since it functions better than the pop-up on the 1250 -- The battery lasts less time than all other SensoTouch models -- Recommended annual blade replacements add significant cost -- There is no indicator for blade replacement or cleaning -- The battery indicator includes 2 stages instead of the 5 on the 1250 -- The battery is not user-replaceable and will limit the unit's life -- Does not include the jet cleaning system -- The soft pouch is not as nice as the carrying case included with other models CONCLUSION For most users, lower end models like the 7310 will work sufficiently well. The 1150 is a compromise, but unless you really need the detail trimmer give the entry level units a try first. Those who want the Jet Clean system should try the 1250, as long as they are willing to pay the premium and don't mind the hassle and expense of changing the fluid. I would still recommend this over the 1250. For a much more reasonable investment of time and funds, you can have an almost equivalent shaving experience. Enjoy.
  83. My first electric shaver was a corded Norelco 2-head razor, state of the art at the time. Since then, I've bounced back and forth between Norelco, Braun, and whatever the current generation of Gillette happen to be (I'm fairly sure I have a handle and at least one or two blades for nearly every Gillette model going back to at least the 80's). I liked my last Braun enough to have the internal battery replaced when it died the first time. When the new battery gave out a few years ago, I started looking for a replacement and found a Norelco arcitec 1050 on sale at Target (shopping hint: the weeks before Father's Day are the best time to find a deal on an electric razor). I thought it would be no problem adapting, but I had painful razor burn and seriously considered taking Norelco up on its money-back guarantee. At this point, I should mention that I've had a beard much of my adult life and so usually shave only my cheeks and my neck, with is both the most sensitive area and the hardest place to get a clean shave with any kind of razor. I toughed it out with the arcitec 1050 and eventually got used to it. The 1050 still has one annoying drawback: it is difficult to throughly clean. The 1050 is one of the models with flip-out heads which makes it easy to rinse but is not designed for disassembly. The result is that longer whiskers get jammed up inside the heads and no amount of rinsing or compressed air will dislodge them. The only way I found to do it was sitting at my desk with a bright light and using a set of picks tiny enough to fit between the individual blades and un-clump the whiskers. Naturally, I was curious to see if the Philips Norelco 1150x/40 SensoTouch had any improvements. The head of the 1150 is a completely different design and is an improvement over the 1050 head: -- The foil is a combination of slots and round holes, instead of just slots. I think I'm getting a closer shave and it's doing a better job of catching longer whiskers (Idon't always shave every day - one of the prerogatives of retirement). -- There are instructions included showing how to completely disassemble the head, if you need to do so. There was, however, one unpleasant surprise. I had just assumed that, because I had been using the 1050 for several years, the migration to the 1150 would be painless. This was not the case. I experienced razor burn for the first week or ten days (I've made a point of using it every morning until I finish the review). It was not nearly as bad or long-lasting as when I first used the 1050, but annoying nonetheless. I was also surprised by razor burn this morning when I used it wet for the first time (with a shaving gel) after having used it dry a few hours earlier. I'm willing to accept that these incidents are a trade off for a perceptibly closer shave and my own experience tells me that my beard growth will adapt. I won't be going back to my 1050 and will still be using my Gillette Fusion occasionally. My advice to new users is to make sure you keep your receipt and all of the packing material until the three-week guarantee time has passed. Electric razors are not for everybody, but they are a great convenience, especially if you don't need to get up and shower first thing every morning (another prerogative of retirement). If you're looking to try one for the first time or you have one that needs to be replaced, the Philips Norelco 1150x/40 SensoTouch is one of the least expensive ways to give Norelco technology a tryout.
  84. Electric shavers ---------------- If you buying an electric shaver for the first time, skip this section and read the next Electric shavers basically come in 2 types - Rotary (philips norelco) & foil (braun & panasonic) Rotaries are good for cutting longer hairs let us say you skip to shave over a holiday then start shaving on Monday morning. Foil shavers are faster and easier to adapt to, since they are very much like your gilette razors, but there are a few downsides - foils are difficult to clean since the hair gets trapped in the inner chamber and foil shavers give you more burn compared to rotary blades. This is a rotary shaver About Philips 1150x/40 ------------------------- This is an excellent shaver for this price level, it is rechargeable, comes with battery power display and can be used with/without shaving cream, but I would recommend using some kind of a moisturizer to stop getting razor burns. Overall, it is pretty effective, quiet, battery lasts more than a week and pretty good around the neck
  85. While I've cut back on shaving my face (ha ha ha), I decided to let my husband review this one for me and he absolutely loves it. Here's his thoughts:<br /><br />Great handle, nice contouring. Smooth, close shave and the battery has lasted a long time... so far! Look is very sleek and the blue color is a nice change from the standard silver or black on his past models!<br /><br />A definite!
  86. very easy to use and gives a close comfortable shave. only drawback is having to change heads to trim. all in all a good shaver and a good value.
  87. I recently replaced my older Norelco with a foil shaver. It was a bad investment, as, over the 4-5 months I owned it, the shaving result was less close than the old Norelco. At the end, the foil began to shred, and I gave up on it. I bought a new Norelco 1150X and have had it for 3 months now. It shaves better than the old one and is not comparable to the foil bladed one. Why did I ever leave the fold. I agree that it's not a blade, but it's close enough, and I get a clean shave in about 45 seconds. Now many months later, I still love this razor. I've replaced the blades once in the time I've had it...not because they needed it necessarily, but because I thought maybe it was time. The blades last for a long time. The battery is excellent. I charge it every couple of weeks whether it needs it or not. Highly recommended.
  88. I haven't used a Norelco electric shaver since I was a teenager in the 1970s. Poor shave, bumps, and rash was the experience at that time. Now three decades later, I try the new Norelco SensoTouch Electric and I have to say with a lot of shaving a wetting the beard you can get rid of a lot of beard, enough to use if you don't have a razor but the shave won't be as close. Also, if you really want to do a thorough job, I find that it's actually quicker to use a razor. But for convenience, rechargeable battery, fit and finish, and light weight, this Norelco has a lot of appealing features. For emergencies, this is a fine product, but don't expect it to replace your daily razor.<br /><br />Update:<br /><br />I discovered that the Norelco does things my razor doesn't: It can get hard-to-get hairs around nostrils and unsightly ear hairs, so I've definitely found a good use for my Norelco.
  89. This Phillips SensoTouch replaced an older corded electric that I had been using. I wasn't too sure about the charging aspect when I first unpacked and set up my new razor. The charging base that it sits in didn't seem to be of the best construction. I guess only time will tell if that proves to be the case. That said, the razor sits down into the base pretty well and charges using contacts at the sides and bottom. As a day to day razor its actually quite nice. I've been using it for several weeks now and its very thorough. It does a good job cutting the hairs along the jaw, above the lip, and under the neck. I find it to be both comfortable and quiet. It may have been a symptom of my aging razor, but the old one made quite the hum as it went about its business, and I was pleasantly surprised by the SensoTouch. I really haven't had a need to pop off the daily head, so I can't comment about the transition to the trimming attachment. It appears as though others have addressed this aspect, and I will entrust you to their reviews. All in all, I think this rechargeable Philips Norelco razor is a good daily shaver and I'm looking forward to continued use.
  90. UPDATE Feb 2012<br />The battery of the 8251XL proved to be okay. I still get a comfortable and quiet shave, and the shave is still close enough even with year-old shaving head blades. Fine shaver - five stars.<br /><br />UPDATE Feb 2011<br /><br />Although I continued to be pleased with the shaver's performance, the battery died after just three months. Unfortunately, it was slightly beyond the time period when it could be returned or exchanged where I bought it.<br />I replaced it with another Norelco - the 8251XL (not available at the moment on Amazon). This seems to be more robust, gives an even better shave and is even quieter, but I'll have to see if the battery holds up better.<br /><br />~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~<br /><br />ORIGINAL REVIEW<br /><br />I don't usually write reviews (except for classical music CDs), and am not a fanatic about shaving. However, this shaver is so good that I felt compelled to write this. I've always owned Norelco's. I tried a Panasonic once, and yes it's a little closer shave. But so noisy. And just how close does a shave need to be anyway? The 1150X gives a plenty close shave, smoothly and very comfortably glides over the skin with no irritation whatsoever, and is simple to clean with a quick rinse under the tap.<br /><br />Best of all, it's whisper quiet, which makes a big difference early in the morning, so different from foil shavers which are so noisy that it seems like shaving with a hedge trimmer. Who needs that racket early in the morning!<br /><br />One other thing - older Norelco's plugged in directly for recharging, but this model comes with a charger stand. Sure, that's one more thing to pack when traveling. But it also means that the shaver is lighter, because the charging mechanism is in the stand, not the shaver. It also allows for a more streamlined, ergonomic, and comfortable-to-hold shaver, compared with older models.<br /><br />All told, the 1150X is an execllent shaver. Highly recommended.
  91. This is just an \\"ok\\" razor. I had a Braun 5 series before this which worked much better. I've had the Norelco for about 3 weeks and it is getting a little better the longer I have it, but still need to work at cutting some hairs. Love the extra trimmer attachment which works great.

  94. As a very long-time Norelco/Philips user I am pleased to say this new model is the best electric shaver I have used yet. As some reviewers have already stated, the first thing you notice is it is very quiet. It also charges very quickly and holds that charge for well over a week. It does a great job on the neck area, and is the first electric shaver I can say this about. A good shave is easy to get in a short amount of time. Only down side I would say is the trimmer isn't as powerful as I would like, takes several cuts and still not a very clean trim. To those who compare any electric to a blade - is this shaver as good as a sharp blade ? No, but, then again, NO electric razor ever is. However, is this razor as good as any other electric I have tried ? Yes, and for those times when a non-blade shave will do this is an excellent shaver.

  102. I'll state the obvious and then explain.. IT IS AN ELECTRIC RAZOR! NOT A FIXED BLADE! People buy Electric shavers and expect it to cook dinner too! Well this shaver won't conduct a cookout or wash your back in the shower, but it still does a real good job at shaving! I am in the U.S. Army and I shave every day. So, to keep up with military appearance, I feel that this shaver does and excellent job! I am yet to find any shaver that gets as close as a fixed blade and won't ever expect to either. However, this shaver gets pretty darn close! Also, as a little note to those inexperienced with electric shavers, your skin has to get used to the fact that you have changed from a fix blade to an electric shaver. That will take about 1-2 weeks. Also, it is best if you wait approx. 15-20 mins. after you wake-up and are walking about to decide to shave. This is because your face is slightly swollen when you get up from sleeping. (Not going into why, just believe me) In closing, if you are interested in buying an electric razor for about 100 bucks, this is the one! OH! AND IT'S GOT AN AWESOME DESIGN! It is comfortable to use and I especially like the stand-up charger!

  105. I have sensitive skin and am very pleased with the comfortable shave that I get with the Metallic Blue Shaver. My only complaint is that the manual is unclear in describing how to remove the heads to clean them.   106. I purchased the Panasonic ES8103S and the Norelco 1150x at the same time and this review is a comparison of these 2 shavers side-by-side. I used both shavers for 3 weeks, shaving one side of my face with the Panasonic and the other side of my face with the Norelco. I didn't switch sides during the test to allow time to adapt to each shaver. Both of these shavers rated nearly the same amongst other Amazon reviewers and were the top-2 rated shavers under $100. I evaluated both shavers on a number of criteria: -- Shaving Performance: I found that both shavers did a relatively good job overall. However, the Panasonic performed slightly better on the flat cheek areas whereas the Norelco did slightly better on the curved areas around the jaw bone and neck. I found that the shavers required different shaving techniques. The Panasonic, being a foil shaver, required an up-and-down or side-to-side motion whereas the Norelco, being a rotary shaver, required a circular motion. No matter how I shaved with the Norelco I could not get quite as close as the Panasonic. After some time I did find a technique with the Panasonic that allowed me to shave my neck and jaw bone area as close as the Norelco. I tried shaving both wet & dry and found no difference. I almost always shave dry and I found the Norelco didn't move as smoothly across the skin as the Panasonic. Overall, I give the edge to Panasonic for a better overall shave. -- Return Guarantee: The Panasonic has a 30-day return policy, the Norelco is 45 days. I actually purchased the shavers from Target and they offer a 90-day return policy. -- Warranty: The Panasonic has a 1 yr warranty, Norelco is 2 years. -- Cutter Replacement: both shavers recommend replacing the cutters at specific intervals. Panasonic recommends replacing the foil every year ($24) and the blade every 2 years ($17). Norelco has only one replaceable part which they recommend you replace every year ($39). If you look at the cost over 3 years, the Panasonic would cost $65 whereas the Norelco would cost $117 which exceeds the original cost of the shaver ($100). -- Charging: The Panasonic has an A/C adapter that can be plugged directly into the shaver and the shaver can be used with the cord attached. The Norelco can only be charged in the included charging cradle. If the battery in the Norelco goes dead you'll need to recharge it before you can use it. Also, the Panasonic has a digital LCD battery gauge whereas the Norelco simply uses LEDs. -- Cleaning: Both shavers can be rinsed under water for simple cleaning. I found the Norelco shaving head somewhat difficult to remove whereas the Panasonic foil was very easy to remove/replace. -- Price: Both shavers sell for under $100. Best price I found on the Panasonic was $80 @ Target. I saw the Norelco for $90 @ WalMart. -- Other: The Panasonic has a built-in trimmer, the Norelco requires that you remove the shaving head and pop on the trimmer head. The Panasonic includes a carrying case, the Norelco does not. In summary, the Panasonic rated higher than the Norelco in all areas with the exception of the warranty. My only real complaint with the Panasonic would be the noise. It is much louder than the Norelco but not so much so that I would return it. Based on my experience, I will be returning the Norelco and keeping the Panasonic.
  107. I had a Norelco wet dry shaver that I had bought in the early 90's. I had a beard for many years but took a position in sales that required a clean-cut look. I was fairly satisfied with it but ended up growing my beard back and only periodically using it. Late in 2010 I decided it was time to shave my beard and the shaver had become dull and the battery couldn't hold the charge. I investigated the new shavers and watched the corporate video for this one. I decided to give it a shot and am very pleased with the results. It is very smooth and doesn't irritate my skin. If I'm in a hurry I just use it \\"Dry\\" with some 'Lectric Shave lotion, but when I have a little more time in the morning I use it with Edge gel and that is really the best combination. The battery holds a charge for a long time too. The only reason I won't give it 5 stars is because I still need to sometimes \\"touch up\\" with a razor - I'm not sure there's an electric out there that deserves 5.

  118. This thing is absolutely fantastic! I've been shaving and waxing my legs for a few years (never you mind how many!) and I have always been disappointed by the not-close-enough job done by electric razors, so I always resort to the disposable razors.<br /><br />This razor seems to get very, very close without even the benefit of soap or shaving cream, which is really nice!<br />I originally got this for my hubby, who has a norelco smart touch XL, which he likes very much, but I don't find that it gives me as nice a shave as this one.<br /><br />However, when holding the two side by side, I have to agree that if I dropped this razor, the small pivoting head part makes me nervous in that it looks so fragile it might break...the XL is more solidly built, but gives less of a close shave, I think (though, the scientist in me wants to conduct an experiment doing both legs, equal amount of passes with each razor to be truely unbiased...heh)<br /><br />In all, I'd have to say this is a fantastic item, and the only minor flaw I see is my own worry that if I dropped it, the small pivoting head, should it land just right, would be damaged...and I'm fairly butter-fingered.<br /><br />I can't hold my own butter-fingeredness against the product design, until such a time as I do drop it and it does break...I'm just looking down the road at a possible flaw, and thought I'd mention it.<br /><br />The indicator lights are great, so you know how long of a charge you've got left.<br />This would make a great gift for a new shaver, long time shaver, male of female, in my opinion!

  126. I tried a norelco once about 10 years ago that I received as a Christmas gift. I forget the model, but it would leave stray hairs here and there and would give me tons of irritation as I have kind of a thick beard and sensitive skin. Over the past few months I figured that electric razors have to be much better now days. I did some research and was undecided between a braun and the norelco. I bought this model and a braun 3 series the same day to see which I like better. I had a thick, 4 day beard and dry shaved each side of my face with both. The braun gave me irritation almost instantly, left stray hairs, and I have not used it since. I will be returning it. The norelco was much more comfortable but left stray hairs as well. The next morning, I used the norelco again with shaving cream and eliminated all the stray hairs. My shaves did get better the more I used the norelco but I attribute that to me learning how to use it more than my face getting used to it. I am very happy with this shaver. I would like to share my technique that gives me the best results. I shower twice a day and I shave twice a day in the shower with cream. Use a light circular motion and rinse the shaver frequently. This razor does not do well with longer hairs but if you keep up with shaving it will cut right through with zero irritation. If you miss a day or two, expect to shave with cream twice to get it close again. I dont think it is quicker or closer than a blade, but It is much more comfortable and does not irritate my skin at all. The shave is close enough to get through a work day with no problem. I assume that the 3D will shave quicker because it has more blades but I dont buy into the cleaning systems because this one washes easily under the faucet once you remove the cutters. Overall, I am happy with this norelco and would recommend it. You just have to change your shaving habits a bit to get the best results. I only gave it 4 stars because it is not better than a blade, it's justa more comfortable alternative.

  137. I've had a few 3-head rotary razors over the past few years, and for the most part, they do okay. I never have liked shaving with a blade, because doing so seems to irritate my skin, no matter what I do. This razor replaced a Remington that wasn't that old, but it was an inexpensive model and was wearing out fairly early, in my opinion. I bought this one because of the updated design, and I thought the price was reasonable. The high end for Norelco seems to top out around $200, but I'm not willing to spend that on a razor...sorry, Norelco. CONS My experience with this razor is that it doesn't really shave that close without spending quite a bit of time. And if I skip a day or two, the experience is worse. My facial hair doesn't really grow THAT fast, statistically speaking...it takes me a day or two to develop a \\"5-o'clock shadow.\\" So I wonder how guys whose hair grows out faster are satisfied with the product. Note that I also shave my head with this razor, and again, it does okay, but not great. I have one gripe with a design issue...there is no way to plug the charger directly into the razor. If you happen to run out of charge, you have to put it in its stand to charge. My experience is that a charge lasts about two weeks. What if you go out of town for, say, 3 weeks?? It appears that you have to take the charging base with you in that case. I like the charging base, and I like the way the razor slips into it, but I don't believe the base is stout enough structurally to survive travel in a suitcase. PROS At around $80, the price is right. Like I said, I'm not willing to spend much more than $100 on a razor. Then again, maybe the more expensive models shave better??? I LOVE that the unit can be cleaned under running water. The heads pop off easily for cleaning. I've had a Remington that had a self-cleaning base, but you had to buy special cleaning fluid and filters, and cleanup was a pain. And the electrodes that ensured you had enough cleaning fluid corroded after 18 months and the unit ceased to function. I note that the more expensive Norelco models have a cleaning base....not interested. The battery life is much better than my previous razor. Even new, that one's battery only lasted 3 or 4 shaves. This one is lasting a couple weeks. The design of the charging stand is elegant, and the razor slips in and out easily. But like I said, it would be good to be able to plug in directly and not have to carry the stand when doing extended travel. So....the design is nice, but the lack of a close shave and the lack of a direct plug to charge takes off two stars. I'm usually pretty generous here with stars, but I expect more from a company like Norelco, so maybe I'm being a touch harsh. I just want a clean, close shave without having to spend 15 minutes at it.
  138. Thank you for such a quality product. My husband was pleased, enjoyed for about 5 months, very clean shave, charging enough for a few weeks, despite the fact that my husband shave every other day. I advise everyone without hesitation.
  139. It is a very nice shaver. Its shape is very smooth and magic. Its color and picture are very beautiful.
  140. This is an excellent Shaver. Easy to operate and smoth. Battery life is good and easy to clean. I would highly recommend this product.
  141. I bought this product because I wanted a high-quality electric razor. I don't like using a regular razor because they irritate my skin. For some reason, electric shavers don't do that. At the same time, however, I've never been pleased with electric razors. That said, I'm happy with my purchase. It shaves very clean everywhere except for my jawline--really just under my jaw/upper neck area. It isn't bad enough that I feel like I need to touch it up with a \\"real\\" razor. Besides, the attachment does a pretty good job doing touch up work.

  150. Bought this when Amazon had a $30 coupon. Also there was advertised a $30 dollar rebate. Just found out that the $30 was the one and only discount and the rebate is void. this was never mentioned on Amazon.com and from what I can see on the net this was a Phillips practice to let people believe they were also going to get the rebate. I would not have bought this shaver having known this. Now I will not buy any Phillips products.<br />Actually the shaver is great and does a great job but I feel deceived by both Amazon and Phillips about the rebate. Why was the rebate sent with the product? It does say on the rebate form that it was not to be used with other discounts. I take that meant that if I got $5 off the msrp then the rebate would have been void. That is like a car company offering a thousand dollar rebate and after signing the papers they say that since the dealer gave me $500 off,I wouldn't be getting the rebate. Who pays msrp? So how many customers are going to be angry when they start learning that they were deceived. I buy a lot of stuff and when a company says that you are allowed only one discount you figure that it means one of theirs but once again it was not stated that the coupon was a Phillips coupon and that took the place of the rebate. A lot of web sites were touting the $19.99 shaver deal....still can see it on the web. Therefore someone was playing with the consumer. No more Phillips for me...when I use all my sonic brush heads up, I will find another tooth brush etc.

  159. Before I give my review, let me just say, I have tried all kinds of electric shavers, cheap ones, moderate ones, and expensive ones. For the last few years I have been using a Phillips Norelco shaver. It worked great, it lasted a long time and I never needed to replace the blades. Eventually, after years of use, it stopped working so I was in the market for a new shaver. I purchased a Braun shaver (priced over $200) and I was NOT happy at all with it. It did not get a close shave, it hurt, it was crap. I then knew I wanted to purchase another Phillips Norelco shaver because of how pleased I was with my previous model. The question was, do I get the Sensotouch 2D or Sensotouch 3D? I decided on the Sensotouch 2D and here is why. The 3D model, as explained by the name 3D, has blades that move in 3 different directions. The 2D model, of course, moves in 2 directions. After careful review of both models, I purchased the 2D model. My rating, 5 out of 5 stars. The 2D model has a very VERY close shave, it is very comfortable, and it is made with very good quality. I am extremely satisfied with the 2D model and would recommed this shaver to anyone! I would only recommed getting the 3D shaver if you need all the extras that come with it. The 2D gives such a close, smoothe shave that I would say the 3D model would just be excessive. Thank you Amazon for having such a great price for the shaver and thank you to Phillips Norelco for making such a great product!
  160. I shave my face and head everyday. I have done this for MANY years. If you look back at some of my previous reviews, you'll see I've tried most things out there for shaving. Just off the top of my head I have used Atra, Sensor, Tracer, Headblade, Mach 3 , Proglide, Hydro5 and yes even Bic and \\"Good News\\" razors. I have also used Braun, Norelco and Panasonic electrics. One can get a pretty good shave out of most items out there.<br /><br />I usually use a blade during the winter months and an electric during the summer months....no real reason other than I like variety, and in the summer I water my lawn so I don't want to use as much water in the shower or shaving. We can make electricty, but we can't make more water. :-). When I am in blade shave mode the Schick Hydro5 is my tool of choice, best blade hands down for me, however this new Norelco 1150x/40 is going to have me using it more than I ever thought possible.<br /><br />Just so you know, I have used the following electric razors:<br /><br />Norelco 4401LC, 7145XL--Overall I am a Norelco fan. They work well for my daily routine and work fast. My 4401LC is a 20 yr old corded model that still does a very nice job/close shave, with HQ4 heads, but I have to be gentle or I'll get razor burn on my neck.<br /><br />Panasonic EA-SA40, ES7037 and ES 7103---Panny makes really, really nice razors. Great wet/dry use. With the amount/type of surface area I have to cover, the rotary seems to be a better fit for my shaving routine. The newer Panasonic do have larger cutting surfaces that I may have to try someday.<br /><br />Braun Syncho5, 1-150-----Braun just DOES NOT work for my beard and head. Gives me the worst shave ever. Missed hairs everywhere, cheeks, neck, razor burn, you name it. I will never buy another Braun. These two shavers could not handle a stoud beard or the \\"workload\\" a heavy shaver like me demands.<br /><br />FYI--I also brush out my shaving heads every week no matter what shaver I use. It makes the heads last much longer.<br /><br />I like electric shavers because they don't cause bumps at the base of the back of my neck like blade shaving does. I also like to shave on the go.<br />I prefer a wet/dry razor because just being able to rinse it out everyday is my preferred (and most cost effective) cleaning method.<br /><br />Okay, so I get my new 1150. First impression was, oh wow it looks amazing!!!!! 100% wow factor there. The base is fantastic, I love it! No tossing this razor in a drawer or cabinet. Having a lithium battery is a big plus as well! AND MADE IN THE NETHERLANDS, not China! COOL!<br /><br />Um wait a minute, the Series 8 heads look JUST LIKE my 7145XL! Is this really an upgrade? Also, the head base seems to flex the same as my 7145...heck this may not be much of a difference of a shave. Well, wait, now the 1150x has this new neck pivot device. Hmmmm. This razor was charged when it arrived and I had some stubble so, HERE IS THE IMPORTANT PART-- I gave it a test run. For some reason with my beard, I only get average results with a dry shave and this razor was no different. RIght side of face, dry shave eh, okay....but my preshave of choice is Afta Pre-Electric (better than Lectric Shave or Face-Saver for me), and on the left side of my face with the Afta...WOW, nano-near as close as a blade!!!!! So put some Afta on my scalp...holy moley, this 1150 contours my scalp/and head like no other razor or blade I have ever used!!! SO CLOSE and SO COMFORTABLE! Also ZERO razor burn on my neck!<br /><br />No matter how soft or how hard you push, I did not get burn, the \\"cushion\\" in the floating heads adjusted for a great shave over all surfaces! After using this shaver, I then took a blade and went over the same spots to see if I could get any closer.....not really. Using the circular pattern (with and against the grain) with this or any Norelco shaver really gives on a close shave. I have used the 1150x for a while, my shave time is getting less and less, and it is very apparent, this is a big step up in comfort and overall shaving experience.<br /><br />---September 2011....I see some folks have gotten this razor for @ $50!!! What a deal on a great razor. This razor is still performing very well. I use it mainly on my face but have also used it on my head. I found that on my face, using Afta preshave makes a nice shave even better. Lectric shave also works very very well. I tried the Remington shave stick which produced a really nice shave, but gosh the residual powder gummed up the razor. I have to say this is still the best electric I have ever used. Close shave,no neck irritation which has always been a big issue for me with other products. I clean the heads by taking it apart and just running the heads under water. They are still sharp and performing well.<br /><br />--- Dec 2014 No other electric I have ever owned is as smooth as this, but my current fave electric shaver is the Remongton F5. 5800.s, and it is very apparent, this is a big step up in comfort and overall shaving experience.<br /><br />---September 2011....I see some folks have gotten this razor for @ $50!!! What a deal on a great razor. This razor is still performing very well. I use it mainly on my face but have also used it on my head. I found that on my face, using Afta preshave makes a nice shave even better. Lectric shave also works very very well. I tried the Remington shave stick which produced a really nice shave, but gosh the residual powder gummed up the razor. I have to say this is still the best electric I have ever used. Close shave,no neck irritation which has always been a big issue for me with other products. I clean the heads by taking it apart and just running the heads under water. They are still sharp and performing well.<br /><br />--- Dec 2014 No other electric I have ever owned is as smooth as this, but my current fave electric shaver is the Remongton F5. 5800.

  173. I purchased this product as I was fed up about replacing the Gillette razor every month. Read the review here and thought it will be good.   174. This review is NOT on the performance of the 1150x/40 SensoTouch 2d Electric Shaver (which is performing well). I am writing this review to draw attention to the 'Buyer Beware' Norelco Rebate Offer - which, in my opinion, is deceptive. I bought the shaver in Nov. 2011 when there was a $30.00 rebate offer from Norelco. Amazon had dropped the price as a 'daily deal' to $49.97 that day. Deal finding sites like [...], [...] had picked it up as a great value at a seemingly out of pocket cost of $19.97. After sending my rebate, I never got ANY acknowledgement from Norelco. So, I checked rebate status online after ~ 90 days. There was no on line information. I talked to the Norelco Rebate Customer Service (agent & a supervisor) in March 2012. They contended that the qualification for the rebate offer specified 'no other discounts'. Since Amazon had a daily deal coupon for $20.00, therefore, the rebate was disqualified. I argued that (a) Norelco did not send me rebate rejection else I would have returned the product to Amazon, (b) I interpret 'no other discount' to mean no additional discounts from Norelco towards purchase price, (c) Amazon had the rebate form link on the same page with no rebate disqualification disclaimer about using the daily deal coupon. They disagreed. I pointed out that (i) their interpretation is non industry standard, (ii) their rebate disqualification does not explicitly state that even retailer's sale/coupon would invalidate the rebate, (iii) they did not notify me of rebate disqualification to allow me to return it back to Amazon. I argued in vain. My conclusion of this behavior from Norelco is the following: (i) The rebate offer is made deliberately misleading - designed to disqualify the rebate based on a loose, 'bait and switch' wording of the fine print; (ii) They choose not inform the customer of rebate disqualification - counting on customer forgetfulness and expiration of merchandise return period; (iii) It is at best an attempt to control customer's end purchase price with a third party vendor. Standard industry rebate programs are typically independent of end use's purchase price from a third party vendor. I called Amazon's customer service. They found this practice non standard. Amazon's Customer Service supervisor offered to provide feedback up the chain of command since it impacts their customers. I would guess that this rebate practice is by an 'opportunistic' marketing idea from a 'smart' US Norelco division to increase next quarter sales by 'any' means. OK. Let me see how Norelco HQ executives react to this 'poop the customer' antics.

  180. I got it today (dec 20, 2011) ordered last week (dec 16, 2011). Took it for a test run, it is really smooth without getting yanked or pulled, contours to your jaw and shaves every hair, assuming you give it a bit of a circular motion The trimmer is also good, doesn't catch or yank on your long beard hairs. Nice clean shave, haven't tested with shaving foam, as it is capable of it (dry/wet)... The cleaning is a breeze, run both trimmer and shaver head through some warm water and you're done, no more brushing out hairs. I do believe it is splashproof while cleaning in the basin, but I don't think it would be wise to use it constantly in water such as in the shower, but not 100% on that. My review is based against an old remington 7 series, so this shaver, I believe is a nice upgrade. No regrets on my purchase...

  190. I have used Phillps/Norelco shavers since I was kid. I've owned the old corded ones, cordless, cheap and expensive ones. (The cheap Norelco razors are like chainsaws-spend the extra). This is hands down the best electric razor I've owned. I'm Italian so my 5 o'clock shadow shows up around noon. Three day old growth was a (lierally) painful experience. No longer. My old Norelco is about 7 years old (6XXX series) and was about $140 when purchased. It did a really good job but with 3 day growth, it actually hurt to shave as my face is somewhat sensitive. When I recently forgot my shaver and came back after 3 days with this one, I expected the worst. I could not believe how smooth and effortless this razor removed the hair. Even the tricky neck hairs were no match. I would recommend this razor. The only thing I don't like is the detachable trimmer and removing the heads to dump the stubble. You have to take the entire head off and snap on the trimmer attachment. I can see that getting old. And to get the stubble out you need to do this 3 fingered push and pull thing. Easily learned but not as convienent as the hinged head assembly on the other models I've used. It removes the hair from my face very well which is it's core function.

I don't think it is something that will change in time (as it is said it takes 3 weeks to adjust) I don't want to mention about the trimmer because it cuts like scissors even worse. I paid attention to it and saw that it has two metal part and the upper part is stable, bottom part is moving. However because bottom part is not forward enough, trimmer can't cut as I want. One of the good parts can be smooth shaving that doesn't require to much power. But as I said you need to go over your face at least 2-3 times. It is light and quiet compared to my old one. So I wouldn't recommend it to you whether your beard is thin or not. Actually I don't recommend any razor that goes up and down while shaving as I told the reason.

So if traveling, you have to cram the stand into your bathroom kit as well. Only other thing is that it doesn't do a great job if you go several days in between shaves (unless your beard grows slow). Sometimes i have to use the side-burn trimmer real quick to get it short enough for the regular razor to be effective. That said, when used consistently, it works well, and aside from the first use (when i wasn't used to it) I haven't really had any razor burn issues. Pretty quick delivery, if I recall.

I DOUBT IT TAKES ME MORE THAN 20-30 SECONDS. THE SHAVE IS GOOD/CLOSE, NO PROBLEMS.<br />WITH THAT SAID, YOU NEED TO CLEAN THE HEADS PERIODICALLY. FIRST YOU HAVE TO UNSNAP THE MECHANISM THAT HOLDS THE HEADS, THEN REMOVE EACH HEAD AND BRUSH THEM, THEN REPLACE THEM THEN RESNAP THE MECHANISM.   224. While this shaver is very easy on the skin, it doesn't seem to get close enough. I had to try it out before I handed it over to my husband to use. I tried it on my legs, most men's shavers don't do well on legs so I wasn't expecting much. While it did trim the hairs it did not provide a close shave which I expected. It was very gentle though.<br />My husband has used it several times now and he has a heavy wiry beard plus his skin can be sensitive. The shaver was very comfortable on his skin and didn't irritate it or make a rash or redness. He did enjoy using it because of the comfort factor. The head is very flexible and glides over the contours of the face easily, it is easy to clean too. It takes longer to shave with this than it does with a razor and shaving cream and the manual razor is much quicker to clean. This Phillips is more for touch-ups than for a real shave or an all the time shaver. I think it is a little pricey for what it does. There are other shavers out there that will shave much closer but they aren't as easy on the skin as this is.<br />I guess it depends on how close a shave you want and how much you want to spend.

  226. I've been shaving for a number of decades and as approach it as a dreaded task. I've gone as far as to experiment with having my face waxed, but the sample site explored was enough to convince me that I'm so glad I'm not going to ever endure the indignity of a bikini wax.<br /><br />I digress.<br /><br />My older model Phillips razor was a decent device, and would have lasted much longer than the 10 years I've owned it, if I hadn't dropped it while cleaning and broken one of the rotators. Since that time, using it was like using a dull saw to hack at whiskers. Ouch!<br /><br />I took a great deal of time searching for a suitable replacement, but really had a price point of being practical. While I like the 3D SensoTouch shaver infomercial, I can't see myself spending $200 on a shaver.<br /><br />I looked for nearly a month before deciding to get the 2D SensoTouch, and it's a good thing. Amazon.com had a great deal of $30 off the razor. Combined with my Amazon Prime free shipping, I paid much less than my price point.<br /><br />I was a bit trepidatious about it considering about a quarter of the reviews were below 3 stars on various sites I read.<br /><br />However, out of the box I liked the design and ease of removing parts to clean. The design also seems far more careful in consideration of moving parts so they are not as easily broken. I wish I didn't have to change the head to the trimmer, but that issue seems to be resolved in the 3D model.<br /><br />I decided to give the new shaver a quick try at a dry shave, with five days of growth on my face. Normally, I need to use the trimmer first to get to a point I don't feel like things are being yanked from my face. However, this was by far the smoothest shave I've ever experienced for five day stubble. It was amazing. My face was as smooth as ice and it wasn't irritated or hot, which is usually the case. I haven't tried it yet as a wet shaver, but I can't wait.<br /><br />Normally, I can't shave day after day since my skin gets irritated, but I tried today and it was just as smooth and comfortable. I was genuinely surprised, thinking that it would be a mediocre shaver at best. What a great decision on my part.as smooth and comfortable.   227. Like others, I bought this in November because of an Amazon coupon and a manufacturer's rebate, and it was advertised as such to take advantage of this. Of course 4 months later Philips states the coupon invalidates the rebate.<br /><br />Onto the shaver, I wouldn't give this a good rating even had the rebate check arrived. It is not powerful enough to do a good job. I've owned lots of Norelco's and must say this is my last. They just don't contain the power they used to in order to give a close shave. It does ok, so if you're able to get it for $20 or less for a first electric, it might be ok as it would be more gentle as your skin gets used to it, but not good overall. Another flaw in my opinion is not having a direct connect charge, again a cradle that will have connectors go bad in the near future. That's a peave of mine, may not matter to others.<br /><br />On the plus side, battery life lasts long if, as true with any shaver, you don't constantly charge it. Use it until you feel it begin to shave differently or tug lately, then charge.<br /><br />Overall, ok beginner, but that wasn't what I thought I was buying, thought this was an advanced model I would used for a long time and get a great deal, neither were true. Disappointed in both Philips and Amazon, will assume this is on Philips and not buy their products again.<br /><br />***Update - Amazon = Awesome, Philips = Awful, there's a reason why this is the only place I shop online.

  231. Over the last year I have been obsessed with having the perfect daily shave. Starting with a Fusion I had by far the closest shave. But it was so close I would have ingrowns. Then I used a double edge razor (Merkur 37C, Feather blades, Proraso cream) for 11 months. This was an amazing shave but taking 40 minutes daily to shave was out of the question. Plus occasionally I would get a duff blade and tear my face up before I realized it was a bad blade. Having sensitive skin I decided to go with a rotary instead of a foil. I just had my second daily shave this morning, wow what a great shave. Almost as close as the DE shave but finished in 12 minutes versus 40. My face wasn't sore from yesterdays shave, all around comfortable. However I did have to use a blade to line up my side burns(that's why I gave a 4 rating). If you are unsure about buying this shaver remember there is a 45 day trial. They just ask you give it 21 days.
  232. This is a nice electric shaver, and I believe it's worth the price. It gives you a nice clean shave with minimal effort, and does not cause any sort of rash or irritation. However, much like the product insert states, your skin will need a few weeks to adjust. The first few times you use the shaver, you'll likely be disappointed with the shave. You'll feel like you have to go over and over the same spot, and it doesn't feel like the shave is quite close enough. However, don't lose heart! Within a few weeks your skin *will* acclimate and you'll be able to get an accurate and close shave very quickly. The charger is sturdy and the shaver settings are easy to figure out.

  239. As a happy owner of a Norelco 7310XL which already has some years of usage I decided to upgrade to the 2d technology when a $ 30 discount for the 1150x became available at Amazon. Unfortunately, some weeks later I have to say I am not pleased at all with this new model. These are the reasons: - The razor heads seem to turn at a much slower pace than the 7310, therefore, a complete shave takes almost twice the time. - Uneven areas are much more difficult to shave closely requiring several aims at different positions. - You can only recharge the unit placing it on its base (no direct cord connection available). That means that if you travel frecuently you have to carry the base with you which obviously is not foldable and looks quite fragile. Also, if the base malfunctions you have to buy a new expensive part while with the previous razors you could just interchange the power cords. The only reason I gave two stars is that the battery life seems to be more than adequate.

Not a big deal, it's easy to do, but it's still an extra step that I didn't have to do with my old Norelco.

The wet shave was also smooth and the unit easy to clean but still not quite as close as a typical 3 to 5 edge safety razor and probably should not be expected to. The unit for the price is a quality, good performance, easy and comfortable product to use. While the charge time and length of charge per the advertisements seem to be accurate I believe 7 to 10 shaves per charge is more reasonable with shave times closer to 4 minutes of duration. For the price range it is a very good unit and I would recommnend it to anyone for a quality shave, trimming and daily useage.

  258. After years of using a Braun electric razor, and finding that it was mediocre at best, I took a gamble and decided to get the Philips Norelco 1150. I expected it wouldn't be any improvement, but figured I had nothing to lose. When I first received it from Amazon, I noticed that the rotary heads had just one ring of blades. I wondered if that would be sufficient. And when I turned it on, the rotary blades didn't seem to be turning very fast. In what seemed like a third strike, I placed the running razor against my hand and it felt like the blades weren't doing anything. And against my face, the razor just glided across, without the familiar pulling action and grinding sound that I had with my old Braun. Yet when I finished shaving, my face was as smooth as I could ever remember. This razor really works. And, most impressively, it even works on my neck, where the Braun was almost useless. I'm not sure what the secret is to the Philip Norelco, but I won't argue with success. There's no razor burn and the results are the best I'm experienced. The only open question is how durable the blades are, and time will tell on that score.

  265. I have used various Norelco and Panasonic shavers for nearly 25 years. I have a very tough, fast growing beard, and my job requires frequent evening events. So, my measure of performance is whether or not I have to shave again before heading out for the night. After several Panasonic Linear shavers (which I use primarly wet with shaving cream), I was excited to try the Norelco 1150x because of its similar ratings and wet/dry capability. The Norelco was comfortable to hold, quiet and had extraordinary battery life - nearly two weeks of long shaves. It performed well in both the wet and dry modes, providing the closest shave I have received from a Norelco. It was a bit harsh and irritating compared to my previous shavers, particularly on the neck where it produced frequent razor burn and some cuts. It was also a bit difficult to shave accurately in harder to shave areas, such as the chin, neck and around sideburns. All in all - good, but not great. However, the Norelco 1150x did NOT shave nearly as close and comfortably as my older Panasonic ES8103S that it was intended to replace. While close, my beard was already back by mid-afternoon and required a second pass for evening events. After several weeks of exclusive use of the Norelco, I pitted it head-to-head against the Panasonic for two weeks, shaving one side of my face with each shaver daily. I even alternated sides to avoid bias. In this head-to-head comparison, the Panasonic came out the clear winner every time, with the Norelco running second in closeness, comfort and reaching hard to shave areas. While the Norelco was close, it just could not match my old Panasonic in any respect. I returned this shaver under Norelco's 45-day money back guarantee policy, and replaced it with a newer Panasonic ES8243A that shaves even closer and more comfortably than my older Panasonic that beat this Norelco. I think this would be an exceptional shaver for those with light to average beards. It really does require a 3-4 week break-in period for your face and beard to adjust, just as the directions say. Be sure to save your original receipt if you're thinking or taking advantage of the 45-day trial.

I would have to say from the moment I switched it on (after it was fully charged), the super quiet motor, or should I say slow sounding motor, gave me some doubts even before I put it to my face.<br /><br />Sad to say, my faith (or lack of it) was rewarded. When I was finished shaving I still had stubble and I still needed to shave with a blade. In addition, either the motion or the heat (not that it felt hot) from the head made my skin red and sore.<br /><br />On another day--not the same day--I tried it as part of a wet shave routine only to yield slightly better results (because of the gel, I imagine) but I still needed to shave when I was finished.<br /><br />I realize everyone's facial hair and skin differs, but this was not the product for me.<br /><br />Because Amazon only give a 2 day money back guarantee with this product (strange policy), I called Philips as there is a 45 day money-back with them. Beware it has to be postmarked 45 days from the day it was ordered--it's not try it for 45 days and then call us to initiate your exchange.<br /><br />The charging base is slightly cumbersome to get the product in and out of & the suction cups on the base were not doing such a splendid job of keeping the unit stable.<br /><br />Apart from my dislike of the product performance, I do like the concept of a wet/dry shaver and it is designed well, feels nice to hold and looks attractive as a device.

  307. This is a very nice razor that does great job on my face and neck. It runs very quietly and feels super smooth on the skin. The charge lasts for weeks before it needs to be recharged. Prior to this model, I had been using the Norelco 8171XL. The 8171XL has been great and I have had no complaints or problems. This new 1150x/40 has been performing just as well if not better in the actual shave department. Because my last model was so good, I do have a couple of complaints. I don't like how you have to fully remove the razors with your hands when cleaning the unit. The later model had a button that would flip up the razors on a hinge to allow rinsing. The other thing I am not crazy about it the the trimmer requires you to remove the entire razor head and snap on the trimmer attachment. Again, the later model had the trimmer attached to the razor and would just flip up off the back of the unit. I really do like that this is a wet/dry razor that can be used with shave creams and in the shower.
  308. My husband has used a lot of different brands of electric shavers over the years, and this one stacks up about average as far as closeness of the shave. What he did like about the SensoTouch was that the shaver is quite comfortable, both the cutting surface and the shape in the hand. It's very smooth and glides easily across the skin, and the head and blades pivot to make easy work of facial contours. He likes to shave in the shower, and until recently, it was difficult to find a good rechargeable shaver that would hold up to true wet shaving. This one works well for wet or dry shaving. I like that that charger doesn't take up much space at all on the vanity and that the contact points are high, so I don't have to worry about a wet countertop causing problems. The battery lasts through several shaves and recharges quickly. Overall, it's a nice shaver. If you've never used an electric shaver, or if you haven't used one in a while, you have to use it for a few weeks before you start getting good results. The user guide will tell you that your beard needs to acclimate, but I suspect that learning how to use the shaver plays a big part of that, too.

  314. I've used a blade for almost all of my shaving for the past several years, and wanted to try out an electric, hoping it would give me fewer razor bumps around the neck. Honestly this electric razor does OK on the face. It will leave you smooth, but it has the feel of brushing your teeth - going over the same area again and again. But it is smooth and less irritating to the upper lip area. As for the neck, I can barely shave it. Maybe mine is more contoured than other guys' necks, but I tried a couple times and just started using a razor. To its credit, when it is used for the neck it is less irritating to this area as well and does yield fewer razor bumps. All in all, I wouldn't buy it again, but if you're used to electrics its worth a shot.

  319. I figured I'd try this Razor out due to all the high review marks it's been getting on Amazon. People said it was the closest shave they ever got, and it even shaved their neckline. (Something no electric I've ever used has done before)<br /><br />So I bought it and gave it a shot. This is what happened:<br /><br />1. Charged up the unit the night before, to ensure full power.<br /><br />2. After my shower in the morning I used [[ASIN:B0015UWUFM Proraso Shaving Soap 5.2 oz (147 g)]] and applied it to my face. Let it sit for about 5minutes to soften my iron hair beard up. I had not shaved in three days.<br /><br />2. Began to use the shaver in a circular motion as suggested by the manufacture.<br /><br />3. Noticed it barely cutting my beard hair on the sides of my face, and had to make multiple passes to get all the hair. I could here the motor struggling to shave my face. (Never a good sign)<br /><br />4. I then tried to shave my neckline. What a nightmare it was.<br />The shaver spun away and I immediately saw my neckline turn red and start to bleed. I've never experienced this before using any electric razor.<br /><br />5. I immediately stopped using the razor, turned it off, cleaned it and packaged it back up and sent it back.<br /><br />My face was a red, swollen, and bleeding mess after using the SensoTouch.<br />I had to use [[ASIN:B000RIAD0W Proraso Pre and Post Shave Cream - 3.6 oz]] to reduce the swelling of my face, and later go back and finish the mess this razor left behind with my trusty Merkur Double Edge Razor.<br /><br />Now a week later, my neckline is still recovering after the beating it took at the hands of the SensoTouch.<br /><br />Previous electric razors I've used always gave me some form of razor burn. Some minor, and some major. But I've never in my life had an Electric Razor cause bleeding before.<br /><br />I don't know how people can rate this razor so high, when clearly it does not cut hair properly around the neckline. Perhaps the people this works for don't have iron strong beard hair like I do, or very thin beard hair.<br /><br />Do not fall for the hype surrounding this product. If you have strong beard hair and neckline hair, save yourself the pain and discomfort, and avoid this product.<br /><br />Pickup a [[ASIN:B000NL0T1G Merkur Model 180 Long Handled Safety Razor]] instead. You're face will thank you for it.surrounding this product. If you have strong beard hair and neckline hair, save yourself the pain and discomfort, and avoid this product.   330. I've used Norelco shavers for 35 years. I have bought them without question, because until this one I've never purchased one that disappointed me. The worst problem with this design is the shoddy construction. The first time I took the head apart to clean it, the pieces fell apart on the counter. Putting it back together is sometimes problematic because the plastic piece that holds the heads together must face a particular way or the head won't stay in one piece. It shaves reasonably well, but the increased articulation of this design still isn't enough to cut around the angles of my jaw, which was the reason I bought this particular model. I also find it annoying that you need the stand to charge it. One more bulky thing to pack if you travel with it.
