  337. I have shaved with Norelco shavers for 40 years and love them. My old Norelco 980XL was top of the line and cost me $85 10 years ago. I have never changed the heads in it. It says self sharpening so why change them. The old one finally quit accepting a charge which is what all my past razors have done. My 980XL had a LCD display panel and displayed minutes of shaving time remaining. It would beep when to much whiskers were built up in the head and needed cleaning. The rotary heads were made of metal. It had a great side burn trimmer attached. It was and has been my all time favorite. I looked long and hard before I purchased the 1180X razor. It is definitely different in style and features than my old one. Well the first shave was sweet and has been every since. I love the fact that you can just wash it out after each use. Shaving in the shower has been great and actually gives a better shave with just a little soap to make it glide over your face. I even offered to let my wife use it for her legs and underarms since she can just wash to get it clean. My face was already conditioned to the Norelco rotary blades so it was great from the first day. I have a light beard but still need to shave everyday unless I am going hiking or working in the yard on the weekend. We will see if it last me 10 years like the old one but right now it has certainly impressed me. I did like the fact that the 980XL could be plugged in to shave when the battery ran down. I have had this one for 3 weeks and haven't experienced a dead battery yet. It doesn't seem as sturdy as the old one but time will tell. It certainly is egonomically designed and looks great. The big difference is in is water proof design allowing me to wet or dry shave. That is really nice. It certainly is a keeper (10 yrs?)

  346. I bought this for myself this Christmas past as somewhat of an impulse buy, and it's probably one of the best impulse buys I have made. Evidently it just gets better from here. I have a fairly light beard with fine hairs plus my skin is not overly sensitive so some one else might get different results than I did.<br /><br />Although I am not an Electric Razor expert as some of the other reviewers seem to be, however I do know when I have had a smooth, comfortable, close shave. I have not used an electric razor for over 30 years, never did care for them. Back then I used a straight blade electric Remington which I definitely did not care for and a Norelco which was good but not great in those days.<br /><br />Until receiving this Norelco I was using the Schick Quattro Razor. It's a good blade razor with 4 titanium blades. It shaved quite well on the straight away's, but around the curves and my neck area \\" where I have hairs going in 3 different directions \\" it did not do well. I had to go over and over again in different directions to get all the hairs. I also have a clef chin which made it difficult for most other razors to shave properly. This Norelco worked great in all areas for me, plus got all those difficult neck and chin hairs with ease. Just started running the razor around the back of my neck when I shave. It's easy to reach and seems to do a good job of getting the pesky, unsightly hair that grows there. These are the ones that make it look as though you should be getting a haircut way before you really need one.<br /><br />As far as the trimmer goes, I have no problem with clicking in the separate trimmer blade maybe every week or so since that is all I will probably be using it. I used it to trim the bottom of my mustache and sideburns and it worked extremely well.<br /><br />This razor is quiet almost seems as though it's not running fast enough to do the job, but it does. It's easy to clean by opening it up and running it under hot water.<br /><br />All and all this is a great razor the best I have used;::: EVER.ttom of my mustache and sideburns and it worked extremely well.   347. I have been using Norelco shaving products for approximately 25 years. Recently, I chose the newer Model 1150x to be an upgrade to my shaving experince. I prevously used the Model 8842XL which is also a very good shaver! The action and the technology of the newer Model 1150x is much improved.I have found it works very well for my use and the texture of my beard and skin! The shaving head on the 1150x is designed to swivel (up and down) with the contour of to shaving pattern. It is a very much improved shaver over the older, former units I have used in the past.The one factor that I don't like is the way the actual blade assembly clips on to the shaving head! I find it more difficult to remove the shaving blade assembly for cleaning than what it should be! This problem is caused by the way the blade assembly \\"unclips\\" or releases from the shaving head. Otherwise..the newer model 1150x is a definite improvement. This shaver is a much better shaving unit than the previous XL models!
  348. There's no significant deficiency with this razor, but it didn't offer a noticeably improved, more comfortable shave either. I like it, but I wouldn't go out of my way to recommend it. A razor review reflects personal priorities as well as previous experience and likes/dislikes. A younger person may strongly perfer its streamlined, cobra-head styling, and light feel. An older person may like the heft and metal head of the previous model. I do, but I've owned four or five previous versions and prefer the smoother gliding metal head compared with the one on this razor. It fits the hand well, and the cutters conform to the face. Nothing exceptional, but nothing irritating in any way. It has great battery life, and the recharge/recharging indicators are useful and not garish. The charging stand is quick and easy to use, an improvement over the plug-in charger of the older models. I like the razor - for me, it's not five-star gotta-have but it's definitely better than three-star mediocre.

This electric razor is great for going on, and around, all of the little bumps and irregularities that no one notices, until you try to get a smooth scalp. I could not be happier with the purchase.

  391. This is a terrible electric shaver. Negative -1 stars, but I cannot do that on Amazon.<br /><br />The design is terrible. The ergonomics are worse. The build quality is atrocious. I won't take this shaver if it was offered free!<br /><br />Let me explain. I am moving on from a Norelco 7775x, which is about 7 years old. I shave every weekday; my old shaver needed a new blade every 14 months or so. The only reason I am replacing my old shaver is because the old shaver is showing signs of wear--it does not turn on every so often, and requires to be on the charging stand for a few minutes before it can turn on again. I liked the performance of the old shaver, but it too suffered from some seriously questionable design flaws (like an atrocious charging base which was just plain unstable for the shaver, but at least stood where it was planted on my granite countertop).<br /><br />I was looking forward to this shaver after seeing all the positive reviews which are now suspect in my mind. The shaver's base has three very terribly designed rubber suction cups presumably to make the unit hold better on slippery surfaces. This is so poorly designed that I want to give the engineer who designed it an anti-award. It is too small and too flimsy to be of use and worse--it makes the unit _less_ stable. What was the point? Don't get me started about the actual base. Flimsy, and very easy to tip it. On that score, Norelco won't get any points from me for the 7775x either.<br /><br />Stop making mens products resemble rocket ships. I don't need a rocket ship. I need a shaver!<br /><br />The last straw was that the shaving performance was insipid, and doesn't feel like the shaver works at all--indeed, it didn't.<br /><br />Philips and Norelco should stop making half-a-million types of shavers. I would very much prefer it if they sold two or three shavers for each crowd, and did it well. They are not fooling me with this piece.<br /><br />This is going straight back to Amazon with no thanks.

  397. The battery died on my 8 year old Norelco, and it had the original heads. But after scoping out the hassle of installing a new battery and the cost of replacement heads, I decided it wasn't worth refurbishing. I was going to buy a cheapie replacement, but stumbled over the $30 off coupon for the 1150x. For an extra $20, I bought the sexy blue razor instead of the stripped down model. It's a work of art, and delivers an amazing dry shave. Don't let the boo birds scare you away from this exceptional bargain. Some of them are probably new to electric razors and had unrealistic expectations. As far as I'm concerned, the shaves from the 1150 come in a very close second to shaves from a blade. Edit: I tried a wet shave, and it was better than a blade. The 1150x is remarkable!

  405. This is my first electric shaver. I prefer a smooth shave but started getting razor bumps. I did a lot of research and stumbled across this one. This shaver gives a really close smooth shave, whether wet or dry it don't matter. It does not cause irritation, and its easy to clean. I've been using it for a few weeks now and I love it. Some people complain but for under a 100 bucks, it easily compares to some of the other more expensive shavers out there. So if you're an African American male, with sensitive skin, and tired of the unsightly razor bumps and burns, then try this shaver. You will not be disappointed. But please try it yourself. Some of these reviews are misleading, and I purchased it anyway. Look at the video's, and check out phillip's website to get more detailed information about the shaver. It lifts hair up off your face, down to the smallest stub. My skin looks so much better. Also if you prefer a wet shave I suggest getting the Tend Skin shaving gel, and Tend Skin liquid to get rid of razor bumps, all three together will give you a phenomenal clear face.
  406. I have owned Norelco shavers for many years but this one is superb. It is so quiet you hardly know it is on. I only use the 1150x dry but you can use it in the shower also. I recommend this shaver for anyone that wants a clean, close shave.

  410. I've had this shaver for a month and so far I'm very happy with it. I get a very decent shave out of it, it doesn't rip my face up, it holds its charge a long time, it's fairly quiet ... It's been not only a nice experience generally, but also the first electric shaver I've ever truly liked. Four or five years ago I tried one of the highly-rated Panasonic shavers and hated it. On my face and with my beard, my shave was lousy and my face got abraded. Mucho blood flowed from my Adam's apple area. This Norelco is gentle and effective -- no blood yet -- though you should know that an electric razor's shave will never be as close as a blade's. As far as i'm concerned, that's OK. I don't need a shave that leaves my face shiny-smooth. Pluses: One battery-charge gives me two weeks of shaves -- impressive. The shave itself (my face, my skin, my beard) is very good. The floating circular heads manage even my Adam's apple area well. It took no time at all for my facial skin to adapt to the shaver. The shaver manages that funny, difficult area just under the nostrils well too -- in fact, much better than my Mach 3 does. A bonus for the aging among us: the shaver is even effective on ear hair. Minuses: The shaver performs well but it feels plascticky and cheap. It's dumb that the sideburn-trimmer isn't built-in (it's a separate attachment). There's also been an odd decision to have the razor drain water down through the middle of its length. That means that some drops of water can run out of the shaver and up your sleeve as you use it. Minor drawbacks (and non-dealbreakers) all, as far as I've been concerned. Tips: Be patient and shave slowly. Don't expect that, just because you aren't using hot water and cream, you'll be getting thru your morning shave faster than you would with a blade. Keep the pressure very light. Pressing down hard on your face with the shaver will irritate your skin and deliver a lousy shave. I get my best shaves with this device by making slow circleswhile barely touching the skin. For some reason I don't do particularly well shaving with this thing right after washing and drying my face. When I try, the device kind of skids around my face abruptly instead of moving smoothly over it. So I just wait ten or fifteen minutes after my morning face-wash to use the shaver. It works fine then. Realistically I wouldn't expect this device to do a good job with a three or four day growth of facial hair. If and when I let my beard go that long, I'll break out the Mach 3 and the shaving cream. But for a basic everyday shave, this thing works really well for me.
  411. I received this item new and in the original box. Shaver took a charge and has held the charge for several days. No issues with the battery life and motor. I am not happy with the charger stand that is required to charge the shaver. The stand is made of plastic and would be easily broken making the shaver unusable. I prefer the older chord capable of plugging directly into the shaver. Shave quality is normal. It is not the close shave promised in advertisements. The shaver is comfortable to hold and buttons work well. Removing the head of the shaver seems a bit difficult until you get use to removing the shaving head from the body. Removal and cleaning is not a smooth process as other models. I have always used Norelco products and have been happy with their longevity and quality. This model I would rate average or lower due to the removal of the head issue and the plastic charge base with no other options for charging.
  412. If you have a bushy beard, it will work perfectly. I think it is a great shaver for current price. But if your beard is not bushy, maybe it can't shave your beard very clean. Just because it is the 2d version ? Overall highly recommend for a purchase.

I did not pay full price for mine - had a $30 coupon and a $30 rebate so the price was unbeatable. Though I would say this is a good valued razor for around $80. I feel that paying over $200 for a few extra features that aren't necessary is silly. Amazon has great customer service and Norelco has a 45 day money-back guarantee so you can't really go wrong giving this one a try.
  453. I always want to buy a shaver to replace my old one, this Philips Shaver has very good design for shaving, and the price is also attractive for me.
  454. I could not be happier with my shaver that I purchased on Amazon. It was delivered to me promptly and on time. Packaging was great and the product was pristine. I use it every day and am very satisfied with the shave I get. Looks great and works even better.

You can shave many times before the battery needs to be recharged again. I would definitly recommend this electric shaver. The only negative thing is you have to change the head every year per manufacturer's recommendation.

  477. Have had this razor for about a week and it works great in the choseness department. I had a remmington foil razor before this which is supposed to be a close shave but it doesn't even touch the closeness of this one. I would have to shave for everyday with the foil one whereas with this one I can go about a day or two without shaving and still have a fairly smooth face.<br /><br />The only drawback is that you will need to use some kind of lube or go with shaving cream if you want a smooth glide over your face. I have tried it wet and dry and still gets stuck in spots and have to twist or go in a circular pattern. Other than that I highly recomend.
  478. I bought this shaver for my husband for father's day in hopes that it might get him to shave more than his standard once per week. I saw a commercial on TV and then researched reviews online and decided it was worth a try.<br />His first time (and only time) using it he tried to shave with a dry face first. He kept wincing as the shaver pulled on his hairs so I asked him to try it with shaving cream. It didn't produce a close shave on his cheeks and as I watched him shave with it I kept seeing little spots of blood emerge as he went over his cheeks and jawline. It didn't have much effect at all on his neck hair. I felt so bad for him I told him he should stop trying to shave with it and he finished the rest of his face with his usual Gillette blade.<br />I may have had better luck with the 3d sonsoTouch version...but b/c the experience with this 2d version I don't think I'll bother with electric shavers anymore.
  479. Bought this product because of the attractive price after rebate. But Philip and Amazon both failed to abide with promise on rebate.<br /><br />The product is ok, but not powerful enough. It spends me twice the time to shave compared to my prior Remington shaver. Three heads design looks fancy but not much of a value.
  480. I had the Norelco architect razor which was great when it was new but after a couple of years and head replacements I didn't want to spend so much money again.   484. I purchased this razor 90 days ago, and have been nothing but pleased with its sleek design, and elegant battery and charging lights. The feel of the SensoTouch's form-fitting grip in my hand, its quiet \\"whirring\\" sound, and fit of its trimming heads to my neck and face are fantastic.<br /><br />As a display item for my bathroom, the SensoTouch gets 5/5 stars. Unfortunately, since day 1, I've had to go over shaving areas 9-30 times in order to get an even, acceptable shave. Yes, you can get a decent shave going over your stubble as little as 9 times, but you'll be forced to bear down on the adjustable head mechanism until it bursts apart. Fortunately, re-assembling the heads isn't terribly difficult, and you get better at it with practice.<br /><br />One particularly praiseworthy aspect of the Norelco SensoTouch is that your shaving performance is hardly degraded when it's turned off.

  487. I used to use the Nivea Norelco, which was a bit of a pain and very messy. I upgraded to this one and not only is it cleaner, its an extremely smooth shave.
  488. I bought this shaver but the $30 rebate advertised on Amazon got rejected by Philips without a good reason. Either the rebate information is misleading or Philips were cheating. I would expect Amazon to investigate this issue.
  489. Bought to replace old, reliable Norelco 7340XL. Been using it for about a week now. Compared to that model, 1150X is:<br /><br />* a faster, slightly closer shave since the drive motor seems to run at twice the rpm of the 7340 (slightly louder maybe)<br />* easier to clean since the head unit is far less complex internally and the base it attaches to is practically flat (not a deep bowl) with nearly flat drive nubs<br />* easier to keep the handle clean since there are far fewer seams and ridges<br />* about 2 ounces lighter it seems<br />* easier to shave along sideburn lines because the head is a thin unit separate from the battery/handle so its clearer to see where the blade are<br />* slightly more expensive to replace blades (+$5) since 1150X replacements include the entire flex head and drive shaft/springs, not just the blades, however this means more of the unit is \\"new\\" each time, so eh<br />* same blade comb design (\\"Series 8\\") and similar blade cutters so shave is similar experience (but drive shafts are NOT compatible with HQ8's - I compared side by side)<br />* slightly less convenient, separate trimmer but then again it is easier to clean too and its still trivial to swap in/out trimmer, so don't worry<br />* faster recharge time (1-2 hours compared to 8 hours) and you can get in a shave after charging just a few minutes from a zero battery.<br /><br />So overall, it was worth it to me to upgrade especially since the 7340XL gave me many reliable years of service so I got my money out of it by now.
  490. I Was called by Philips yesterday to tell me that my rebate will not be honored because of the \\"May not be combined with other offers\\" clause on the rebate. If A rebate is being offered on Amazon, Amazon or the manufacturer need to step up and do the right thing. This is a play on words and disingenuous at best by either or both parties. I do not understand this type of behavior by manufactures: They may have saved $30 this time, but the cost to them is much higher when I do not purchase their products in the future in lieu for another brand because of the bad taste they have left in my mouth. Bad business.<br /><br />The razor is only worth about $20 (what it would have cost if I got the rebate), it is not very good and would not have bought it otherwise. Philips, you are not right! i will remember this, you can bank on that too!
  491. When I ordered this product, it indicated there was a rebate. I submitted the rebate form after I received the product. After several months, I was noticed that it was a mistake and no rebate for this product since I bought it from Amazon online.
  492. I REALLY wanted to like this electric razor. I've been shaving since 1955, and have had everything from an Eversharp Shick Electric Razor to the first two-rotor blade Norelco to a Panasonic that was a wet/dry (which sounds like a vacuum cleaner in more ways than one). My most recent electric was purchased about 20 years ago, and it's a Braun which is all I can compare to this Norelco 1150.<br /><br />Overall, the price of blade shaving has been quite a bit higher because of the price of blades (it's very much like color printers and ink), but one of the instructions on the Norelco box was to replace the shaving head once a year. In the area of cost, the edge - so to speak - goes to blades depending upon how tough a beard you have and how often you have to shave and change blades.<br /><br />My preference has remained blade shaving, starting with a GEM of all things, and then to Gillette Blue Blade, Thins, Atra, and on and on up to the M3 Power Gillette. Along with Absolute Comfort Shave, there's just nothing as close or comfortable than a blade. And yet there's always this hope that someone will come out with an electric that can compete.<br /><br />Now comes the Norelco 1150, the low end ($99 versus $359) of their newest line. Although it said that a carrying bag was included, I found none ... and I looked four times. Since it's only a \\"bag,\\" I figured I could always use a sock to protect it while traveling. I've actually shaved four times, once with cream in four days, and here are my findings:<br /><br />PROS:<br /><br />1. It has a quick-charge feature which is only 3 minutes, and a full charge in 40 minutes. That's fantastic IF your need the quick charge. (My Braun is a cord model.)<br /><br />2. It is extremely quiet. In fact, having become used to the raucous hum of older electric razors, the Norelco doesn't SOUND powerful enough to shave.<br /><br />3. It can be used wet or dry. I highly recommend \\"wet\\" using a heavy (what used to be called \\"brushless\\") shaving cream which with electrics can be messy.<br /><br />4. The manual states that you should give the razor three weeks before you start complaining. Okay, it doesn't say that exactly, but it does say to use it for 21 days to get your skin used to this electric razor. Since I use my Braun every two or three weeks for quick touch-ups, I didn't think this was necessary. Besides, I've ALWAYS had razor rash from electrics, and to some extent blame electrics for \\"training\\" my beard to go in all different directions.<br /><br />5. That said, this was VERY comfortable until I overdid the neck area. A little powder has always been soothing, and I sometimes recommend using powder BEFORE using an electric razor.<br /><br />6. The trimmer actually trims sideburns nicely and straight, but (read CONS)<br /><br />7. There's a 45 day money-back guarantee.<br /><br />Before I get to the negatives, please take into consideration that I've always had a heavy beard and sensitive skin. And now that my beard is half-gray, the gray hairs are even more wiry than the black. (I must say that my two sons-in-law who were \\"consulted,\\" said the following: the one with a light beard said that he got razor rash from any electric. Then there's Paul who, when he's on a speaking tour, has to shave two to three times a day, can't use an electric because the heads wear out in a month and he does not get a close shave. No, he's no relation to King Kong, but fair warning to those of you who understand this situation.)<br /><br />CONS:<br /><br />1. Sorry, but the Norelco 1150 simply could not shave neck hair that was more than a quarter- to a half-inch long, and it was not good in what is becoming a NECK with creases.<br /><br />2. It was my attempts to get these longer hairs at the base of the neck and between my lower lip and chin that culminated in a rash. It was not as severe as my previous electrics, but it still was a .... pain in the neck. In the old days, for me this would have led to ingrown hairs. I think if you have a light beard and shave daily with this Norelco, you'll get better results and may well love it.<br /><br />3. As I said, the razor is good, but even better with shaving cream. However, cleaning is a chore. You can wash the head after easily removing it, and you can brush the hair out of the receptacle under the heads. But, when you come right down to it, I can shave with a blade and clean up faster than with the Norelco (or any other wet/dry electric.<br /><br />4. As I said, the trimmer actually does trim and does it well. However, you have to take the head off and insert the trimmer in order to just do sideburns. This isn't terribly time-consuming, but it is an added step in the shaving process. It also gives you another thing to clean.<br /><br />5. It has a large footprint: The base for the razor isn't huge, but it does take up enough counter space. The base has three small suction cups, two of which did not hold on our marble top even after cleaning the top. Bigger suction cups would be good, but in a bathroom where there is powder and other things that get on the counter, I wouldn't leave it out providing I have a drawer that can take a razor that is light but bulky.<br /><br />6. Both the Norelco and my Braun do a great job on the cheeks, but the Braun does a better job on the neck. The Norelco is more comfortable, and there's a irresistible urge to go over and over the same spots, especially now that it's almost silent. And, surprise, the Norelco actually does a good job of getting ear hair. (Nose hair? Use a small scissors.) It's comfortable to hold.<br /><br />It's not entirely fair to ask ME if I would recommend the Norelco 1150. I've been shaving with a blade for 55 years, and only intermittently with electrics. Considering that while I absolutely hate shaving, but don't feel clean without having shaved, I'll stick to the soap and lather and my trusty blades which now last a little longer than they used to. But a hundred bucks for a razor? Or go for a steam cleaned Norelco for $350? That's a lot of bucks under any circumstances.<br /><br />I believe that the statistics are 72% blade, 20% electric, and the rest with beards (I guess). My father-in-law NEVER in 70 years used anything but an electric, and he always seemed clean shaven. If he were still alive, I might well have given him this Norelco for Christmas. In many respects - unfortunately other than closeness - there's a certain WOW factor to the Norelco.<br /><br />That's as fair as I can get.irs. I think if you have a light beard and shave daily with this Norelco, you'll get better results and may well love it.<br /><br />3. As I said, the razor is good, but even better with shaving cream. However, cleaning is a chore. You can wash the head after easily removing it, and you can brush the hair out of the receptacle under the heads. But, when you come right down to it, I can shave with a blade and clean up faster than with the Norelco (or any other wet/dry electric.<br /><br />4. As I said, the trimmer actually does trim and does it well. However, you have to take the head off and insert the trimmer in order to just do sideburns. This isn't terribly time-consuming, but it is an added step in the shaving process. It also gives you another thing to clean.<br /><br />5. It has a large footprint: The base for the razor isn't huge, but it does take up enough counter space. The base has three small suction cups, two of which did not hold on our marble top even after cleaning the top. Bigger suction cups would be good, but in a bathroom where there is powder and other things that get on the counter, I wouldn't leave it out providing I have a drawer that can take a razor that is light but bulky.<br /><br />6. Both the Norelco and my Braun do a great job on the cheeks, but the Braun does a better job on the neck. The Norelco is more comfortable, and there's a irresistible urge to go over and over the same spots, especially now that it's almost silent. And, surprise, the Norelco actually does a good job of getting ear hair. (Nose hair? Use a small scissors.) It's comfortable to hold.<br /><br />It's not entirely fair to ask ME if I would recommend the Norelco 1150. I've been shaving with a blade for 55 years, and only intermittently with electrics. Considering that while I absolutely hate shaving, but don't feel clean without having shaved, I'll stick to the soap and lather and my trusty blades which now last a little longer than they used to. But a hundred bucks for a razor? Or go for a steam cleaned Norelco for $350? That's a lot of bucks under any circumstances.<br /><br />I believe that the statistics are 72% blade, 20% electric, and the rest with beards (I guess). My father-in-law NEVER in 70 years used anything but an electric, and he always seemed clean shaven. If he were still alive, I might well have given him this Norelco for Christmas. In many respects - unfortunately other than closeness - there's a certain WOW factor to the Norelco.<br /><br />That's as fair as I can get.
  493. I'm 45, been shaving for ages now, and I have to say, of all the razors I've owned that are of an electric model, this one is the first one to do the complete job. What I mean by that is with electric razors of the past, I'd shave my cheeks and moustache area, and that'd all go well. When it came time to shave the hair on my neck, not so good. I'd have to do that part with a blade. Which kind of defeated the purpose really as I preferred electrics. I would replace the blades, tried a few models over the years, and I'd still have to do cleanup work (if not all the work depending on the specific unit) with a blade.<br /><br />This new one though deals with the neck hair, too. I have thick course neck hair, a lot more course than the stuff on my cheeks, and I when I tried my neck hair with this new razor, I wasn't expecting much. To my surprise, it worked! I was stunned, as I've never had an electric that's done that for me before.<br /><br />I give this thing five stars quite easily, and without exaggeration. Feels nice in my hand, too. The heads collapse and move around to contour to my face, which is probably why it works on the neck hair so well. A lot of my previous electrics were \\"hard heads\\", which didn't contour much - if at all.<br /><br />If you have hard to shave neck hair, I suggest trying this razor - it worked for me!<br /><br />UPDATE (Jan 20, 2011): I posted this review in September 2010, and after I wrote it, I continued to use the razor after that. I can add that the battery life was most excellent. I did not have to recharge it until early January, so the battery lasted for about 3.5 months. Now I didn't use it every single day, I'm a \\"shave every 3 days\\" kind of guy, but still. That was a long time between charges. I continue to be most impressed with this razor.<br /><br />UPDATE (Nov 25, 2011): Still going strong. Replaced the heads a month or two ago, and is still my primary razor. Very happy with this one.<br /><br />UPDATE (Jul 18, 2013): Still going as my primary razor.<br /><br />UPDATE (Nov 9, 2014): Still going as my primary razor. :)ul 18, 2013): Still going as my primary razor.<br /><br />UPDATE (Nov 9, 2014): Still going as my primary razor. :)
  494. I have used several different Norelco electric razors as well as a few made by other manufacturers. While other brands seem to work better for some people, the Norelcos I've used have been far superior compared to any of the other brands I have tried. This particular razor is very good for its price. It gives me a close shave fairly easily. I do have to go over areas several times but that has been my experience with all electric razors. So, the amount of irritation a razor produces is what is most important to me. This razor causes very little irritation. Another plus is that it has a trimmer that works well. Both the shaving head and the trimmer are easy to clean. I have found it is very important to clean regularly (about once a week works for me). For a pre-shave lotion you may want to try Williams Lectric Shave w/Green Tea. I am not sure what green tea does for a shaving lotion but I like it better than the Williams Lectic Shave without the green tea. I'd recommend Williams Lectric Shave Tenderface but I don't think it is made anymore.
  495. I purchased this shaver for my husband who has NEVER used an electric shaver.<br />Due to medications he could no longer use a regular blade razor. I thought he<br />would hate it or would not give him a good close shave. He absolutely loves it<br />and most likely will not return to blade shaving, even if the medication is no<br />longer necessary. I am soooo very happy I ordered this shaver.
  496. I recently got this for my teenage son as his first shaver. When it came in, I got tempted to try it myself. The last time I used an electric shaver was over 20 years ago and things have certainly changed yet some remain the same. I have been using Gillette blade razors for a number of years now (model varied over time) and did not have any problems, just wanted to try the fancy new \\"blue\\" electric shaver. Pros: The Norelco 1150x/40 is very quiet and smooth and you don't really feel the vibrations. The shaving is also pretty good. It does a good job on the side of the face and the chin area, while the neck part is OK. It is still a lot better than some of the old shavers that I used to have, but the neck are is still a little tough. The trimming attachment does an amazing job and is very easy to use. It is a very quick click (just a pull) to remove the shaving blades and click in the trimming attachment. Cleaning is also very easy, just pull of the blade and run it under water. Although I have not used it for too long, the charge seems to be very good. Cons: I still get razor burn on my neck area after using this, which I do not get from blade razors (still working on different things to try and eliminate this). Also the shave (at least for me) is not as close as from a blade razor. Overall, a great shaver that allows you a quick shave, if you don't have the razor burn problem.
  497. It doesn't cut me it's easy to clean, it shaves close. It shaves wet or dry and does a great job either way.
  498. Long ago (35 yrears), I had settled on the Norelco approach to shaving as the best for me and thought there was little else Norelco could do to improve. After all, a charge lasted for weeks, no nicks, cuts or razor burn while getting a close quick dry shave. However, when faced with the need to replace the head on my Norelco Artic 1060 (it lasted five years) I opted to try the 1150 given a replacement head for the 1060 cost $50 and the new razor was only $89. What a surprise when I encountered electric shaving using shaving foam! This truly changes the shaving experience. I would recommend this razor to everyone that is tired of the nicks and cuts from using a blade.

  503. I've owned 4 Electric Shavers in the past 30 years and they all suck. If you don't mind shaving twice a day then get which ever one is cheapest as they all perform about the same. This particular shaver is worth about 20 dollars. Philips-Norelco and Amazon have marked it up to a ridiculous level. You would do better finding a $19 unit as it will work just as well. Anyone who claims that an electric shaver shaves as close as a blade is lying to you.<br /><br />With razor cartridges approaching $5 each it is certainly tempting to consider an electric shaver as a cost effective alternative. Unfortunately, they just don't live up to the advertising hype. It does not matter how slick/sleek they make them look. It does not matter how many hot women they put in the commercials. These things just don't do the job. You would do better buying lottery tickets with your money as you might actually pick a winner. With electric shavers there is no chance of picking a winner.

  506. I have been a razor user for 40 years. Each time I have tried to go Shaver it failed miserably. They just did not get close enough, and you caused such abrasion that the face felt raw. Two thing. I did not know that you must \\"condition\\" the face for 2 - 3 weeks for the face to be accustomed to using an electric shaver. Secondly, the shavers have come a long way in getting a comfortable and closer shave. I say closer, because they still dont quite get the same closeness of a razor, but it is an acceptable shave. I have been using now for about 3 months. The closeness of the shave is so much better that this is all I use now. It is especially good on the neck whereas even with a razor I have had some trouble. All in all I enjoy using. Using once a day I can easily get two weeks out of a charge. The charging is simple although I would have preferred a connector for the charger on the shaver itself rather than only on the charging stand. But, since it holds a charge for over two weeks it suites my just fine.

  508. I bought this shaver on April, 2014<br /><br />I love the warranty; it is already dying, exactly 2 year after the warranty expired. I haven’t been able to get more than 2 years on these Phillips / Norelco shavers.<br /><br />I use them while I am taking a shower, so the chances of water getting inside them is high, but that’s what this one’s suppose to be capable of doing.<br /><br />Some water got inside and it corroded the terminals that charge the battery. It will require me some soldering to fix it<br />Also some grinding noise coming from the heads<br />Motor a little bit rusting, but it is working.<br />Battery still good<br />Electronic board has some corrosion but no short circuits / no salts have developed between terminals.<br /><br />Prices in Phillips keep getting higher and higher to a point that it is becoming ridiculous, so it is time to give a chance to my Chinese friends, and try one of theirs.<br /><br />I will attempt to fix the Phillips shaver so I can get another 30 days while I look for a replacement, I will be playing some roulette and I am planning to get one of those China brands look alike, that are in the range of $24. And suppose to also be wet /dry (If the china brand lasts 1 year I am ahead of the game).<br /><br />I will keep you posted
  509. I've used this shaver for over a year now, and I'm generally happy with it. It gives a close shave and has a long battery life - which is great if you keep it in you car for a few days.<br />On the down side, using it when you haven't shaved in a while makes for an uncomfortable shave. Other Norelco's I've owned are better with longer hair and with the neck / problem areas.

I bought it just so I could try a rotary shaver, but really didn't expect it to be any better than my others. As it turned out this is the best shaver I ever owned. It takes me about 3 minutes for a full shave and the neck hairs are gone. You still must go over the same area more than once and hold the skin taut in the area you are shaving, but not to the degree where it is a problem.

  520. I was forced to buy new shaver, because cap on my old one broke (and Norelco no longer makes it as a spare part). My SmartTouch XL 9160 XL is more than 5 years old and still works great. That was my favorite shaver. I would still go with it, if it was still on the market. I'm not too happy with this shaver and here is why. Philips cheap out on parts I can see that after a week of use of that shaver. -Removable trimmer. Of cause it's much cheaper for a company to just make it removable rather than have some kind of flipping mechanism. If you travel this is an issue for you. Carry shaver and a small part with it is absurd. -Battery's life of my Smarttouch is way better than 1150x. Period. -Battery indicator. Smartouch has 5 bar multicolor battery indicator. 1150x had just one tiny light that tells you that you are screwed if it light up. -Charging. You must have a stand for 1150x to charge it. My old one did not need a stand for a charge. I could just unplug the wire from the stand in plug it into shaver. -Power button. Extremely stiff on 1150x -1150x Has no skin type adjustment. SmartTouch has a wheel that has 3 positions for Normal and sensitive skin. -1150x No head cap flipping mechanism. Although I can not say that 1150x shaves worse. There are things which need the improvements.
  521. I have been using a Norelco shaver ever since I started shaving, many,many years ago. twice in my life I have changed brands.First time, I was given a Remington as a gift, which looked like a Norelco..it was NOT!!!!I had to give it away.. About six months ago for some unknown, insane reason, I was convinced to try a braun shaver..saw to many T.V. ads I guess. I tried it from November 2010 until April 2011...I was in shaving hell for six weeks..Lesson learned!!..Its NORELCO or Phillips Norelco as they are called now or nothing at all. again I say, lesson learned.. In may 2011 I purchased a new Norelco 1150 model... I accually enjoy shaving..Its not a long tedious chore like it was. I can shave my face and neck very quickly and smoothly. What a difference. also, if you have tried a Braun razor you know what a loud razor sounds like.its like starting an outboard motor.. I highly recommend the 1150 model, depending on features you want. My next Norelco will have a charging meter to tell me how much shaving time I have left.The 1150 gives you over two weeks of shaving time so its no big deal,but like I said, my NEXT razor..Years from now..I will never buy another brand of razor..I know I sound like an ad myself, NOPE just a man who wants to help someone learn from my mistakes .This is my first letter of praise of any kind, ever. thats how good my 1150 is..

  541. I must say; up until now, I thought safety razors with double edge blades were the most economical razors since there was hardly any waste other than your own blood. In addition it is much more fun to shave with than the scary de razor; I have now decided to discard my de razor, brush, and soap; I will not be needing those anymore now that I have this more up to date form of shaving; shaving my face dry is a simpler, more convinient way to shave. Thus, by eliminating unneccessary shaving products and just using this razor to shave my face dry, it leaves less of a carbon footprint on the planet. I just wish I could have found this sooner.

The reason I give it ONE star: 1) I was almost bleeding on my neck. It irritated the heck out of my skin! 2) It did not shave of the hairs on my neck cleanly, and I had to rotate it back and forth and around multiple times before it shaved the hair on my face. 3) It took more time to shave than if I were to use a normal Mach 3 razor. 4) It is not good where you have to trim, like making a straight line on the sideburns. 5) My skin was irritated during the second shave as well, when I used water and shaving cream! It wasn't a \\"REFRESHING\\" shave as promoted in the videos. Now I know that user manual said that it is normal to feel skin irritation upto 21 days of normal use, but I wasn't satisfied by the fact that the shaving time equaled or exceeded the time required to shave when I am using a normal razor. Return the product promptly. I am really disappointed in this product...

  603. For the cost that is asked, It is not even remotely as decent as it should be. Out of all the electric razors I have had (3), this is by far the worst. It has so many quirks, and the &#34;ergonomic&#34; design does not contour as it should. Even the amount of facial hair left after shaving leaves me frustrated and ending up using my razor. As for doing this with or without shaving cream, the difference is slight to none. It feels as if without shaving cream you're constantly dragging your skin and irritating it more then necessary. With shaving cream you're just moving the cream along your face and almost no hair is removed. As for the accessory provided for lining up your hair or facial hair, not even that does he trick correctly. Very unhappy with this purchase, If I could return it I would.
  604. I tried it once. It seems it is much easier to use from former model from same company. You will need to shave few times to cut to the end but it is sure it slides on your face like cream on hot bread. I liked the previous model, I like this one.

  608. I got one for my dad, uncle and grandpa. They really liked it. It was easy to use and gave a close shave.
  609. I've been using a Philips Norelco arcitec 1090 Men's Shaving System since December, 2007. I've enjoyed the 1090 and use it regularly whenever I use an electric shaver rather than a blade. This review will serve as a comparison between the two Norelco shavers.<br /><br />Cost: The 1150 is considerably less exepensive without taking any special offers or discounts that may become available into account.<br /><br />Bells and Whistles: The 1090 has more bells and whistles. It has an LED display that shows you how much time is left before recharging is necessary. The 1150 does not. The sideburn trimmer is attached to the 1090. With the 1150 you need to change the shaving head to attach the trimmer. The 1090 is a bit easier to clean. You can just flip up the shaving heads and clean it quite easily. With the 1150 you need to remove the cleaning head off the body of the razor in order to clean it out. It isn't difficult by any means but it does take just a little more time for cleaning.<br /><br />The Shave: My experience has been that the 1150 gives me a much cleaner shave and does so in less time and with less effort than the 1090. This may be due to the curved shaving heads that seems to follow the contours with more efficieny. This is particularly true in those areas underneath the chin and jaw-line. I have to do less stretching and craning of the neck to make sure the shave is completed.<br /><br />Bottom line: For me the lower cost and the more effective shaving experience outweighs the bells and whistles found on the 1090. For those who like the bells and whistles you may prefer the 1090. So if I'm looking to pick one to take on a trip or for when I need a quick shave I'll take the 1150.
  610. Feels good on the face. Great design. That said, however, I have a sparse light beard that should be easy to get a close shave. With a better electric razor I don't have to shave but every other day. Not with this model. This razor is at best O.K. Suggest: spend the extra money and get a couple of steps up in quality.

  669. The design on the SensoTouch is quite futuristic, with a blue front, curved body, and perched shave head. It fits comfortably in the hand, and has a rubber ridge that runs around the edge for added grip (especially useful when using the shaver wet). The shaver has only one button on it, the power button, which is flush with the front of the shaver face. On the shaver front are also three indicator lights. They display low battery, battery charging, and control lock status. The control lock lets you disable the power button to prevent it from accidentallyturning on (when traveling for instance). One annoying aspect of the shaver's design, however, is that it is close to impossible to lay the shaver down without it turning on its side, and then dumping out some shavings onto the counter. You just have to remember to place the shaver back in the charging base if you have to stop mid-shave.
  670. It is a good razor. Very comfortable and easy to use. Hasn't given me any razor burns and the shave is much smoother and closer than I expected from an electric razor
  671. I am using for more than 2 years now, I feel this is a great product from Norelco. I have thick body hair and it does it's job effectively like a razor would do. One issue is that, you need to hold in one particular angle from skin to make a smooth painless hair removal

  680. I've had Philips Norelco shavers before, and this one is pretty much the same. They all shave well enough and I mainly use them when I travel (about 10~12 times a year). I don't take the charger with me and they all last at least a week. I've never had any quit on me. I use them in the hotel showers and they work well. At home I use a standard wet shave (Dollar Shave Club razors with the Dr Carver's Shave Butter. Outstanding.) Anyway, back to the review... I have a heavy beard and they never have any problems with mowing the grass. Takes longer than a straight shave, but that's to be expected.<br /><br />My issue is this: How long before you can't get the replacement blades for this model? With every razor I have, the *only* reason I have purchased a new one is because I can't get replacement blades for the one I have. After a few years, they stop making replacement blades and force me to buy a new one. Shame on Philips Norelco for that. The shavers are nice, but the company forces you to buy a new one every so-many years.

You can do a \\"speed charge\\" in a few minutes - but that just adds time and if you're running late...   687. Purchased this over a year ago. The razor itself works decently, but I've found a few flaws. One being that there's no way to \\"lock\\" the head into place, so if you are an aggressive shaver you will eventually end up popping the head right off. The second one, which is the worst in my eyes, is that the plastic on the body can break or flake off. While at the bottom of the razor isn't a huge issue, my razor has actually had the plastic broken right by the on/off button. There's actually a hole where the plastic has broken off and more cracks spidering from the top of the button as well. I would not buy something like this again unless they changed a few things for the next generation.

  694. Purchased this shaver as a backup to my Brawn. I'd been successfully using various Braun shavers for abou 20 years and wouldn't have even considered purchasing this one except for a combination coupon/rebate deal which made the price too good to pass up. Once it arived I tried out this Norelco it once or twice to test it out and wasn't overly impressed.<br /><br />Then almost a year later my Braun died and I swithced over to using this shaver on a daily basis. I still wasn't overly impressed for the first week or two of daily use. I always used my Brauns without any skin prodcuts but I quickly discovered I needed a preshave lotion to facilitate a smooth shave with the Norelco. Then I remembered it was a Wet / Dry shaver and decided to give it a try in the shower.<br /><br />Wow, the shower is where this little puppy shines. I use a little hand soap lather on my face and voila, this shaver works like a champ. My shower shave is quick and close and best of all I'm doing it while staying comfortably warm in the shower. I get 2-3 weeks of shaves out of it before it needs recharging and I've had no problem with soap buildup on the foil since I make sure to briefly rinse it out after each shave. The soap & water also provide excellent lubricant which facilitates a faster shave. It may sound odd, but I can move the shaver around my face faster with the soap/wather greasing the skids, so to speak.<br /><br />Overall I'm extremely please with this Philips Norelco shaver.

  699. It's a good product, a typical razor. I'm pleased with it but it's nothing to scream about.<br />I recommend it to others.
  700. The Philips Norelco SensoTouch electric shaver is very nicely designed and constructed. It shaves closely, but does have a few annoying design elements.<br /><br />The design on the SensoTouch is quite futuristic, with a blue front, curved body, and perched shave head. It fits comfortably in the hand, and has a rubber ridge that runs around the edge for added grip (especially useful when using the shaver wet). The shaver has only one button on it, the power button, which is flush with the front of the shaver face. On the shaver front are also three indicator lights. They display low battery, battery charging, and control lock status. The control lock lets you disable the power button to prevent it from accidentally turning on (when traveling for instance). One annoying aspect of the shaver's design, however, is that it is close to impossible to lay the shaver down without it turning on its side, and then dumping out some shavings onto the counter. You just have to remember to place the shaver back in the charging base if you have to stop mid-shave.<br /><br />Speaking of, the shaver charges somewhat unconventionally. It has a base that you drop it into and it charges through contacts on the side of the shaver. A complete charge takes 1 hour, and lasts 40 minutes. The low battery light alerts you when there are 5 minutes of shave time left. The only disadvantage to this system is that you cannot use the shaver while it is plugged in. If you're like me and put off charging till the last minute, you may find yourself out of juice when you need to shave in a hurry. A quick charge feature allows you to charge the shaver for 5 minutes, and get 3 minutes of shaving time, but sometimes 5 minutes is more than I have when I'm in a rush. It would be nice if there was a charging port on the shaver itself to use it corded as well.<br /><br />Shaving with the SensoTouch is kind of odd at first. The shaver puts very little pressure on your face. At first I didn't think I was pushing hard enough to get a close shave, but it was shaving just as close as any other electric shaver I've ever used. Indeed, you can push as hard as you like, but it never feels like you're pushing down hard. I've learned to use the SensoTouch with a light touch, and the payoff is a close shave with less irritation. The shaver head pivots smoothly in all directions, and the three shaving heads pivot individually as well. The shaver screens have holes for shorts hairs and slots for longer hairs. Indeed, I had no problem getting a close shave on the contours of my face and around my goatee. The shaver can be used wet or dry or with shaving cream. I only ever used it dry, as I had no need to attempt a closer shave, and liked the convenience of a dry shave. Lastly, you can pull off the shaver head and pop on a trimmer head. The downside to this setup is that the trimmer is a separate piece, whereas most shavers have the trimmer integrated into the shaver itself.<br /><br />Cleaning the shaver could not be easier, after each use you simply pull off the top plate of the shaver head and run water through it and the shaver head. When a more intense cleaning is needed you can disassemble the entire shaver assembly and clean out each rotary blade individually with the included brush (I actually throw the blades and heads into the dishwasher on a sanitize cycle to get them extra clean).<br /><br />All in all... a smarty styled shaver that gives a close and comfortable shave.<br /><br />09/27/2010 Update: I've noticed that even if I don't shave, and let me beard grow for a few days, the shaver still shaves very closely and does not snag on the longer hairs. My old shavers used to snag when I didn't shave every few days.enough to get a close shave, but it was shaving just as close as any other electric shaver I've ever used. Indeed, you can push as hard as you like, but it never feels like you're pushing down hard. I've learned to use the SensoTouch with a light touch, and the payoff is a close shave with less irritation. The shaver head pivots smoothly in all directions, and the three shaving heads pivot individually as well. The shaver screens have holes for shorts hairs and slots for longer hairs. Indeed, I had no problem getting a close shave on the contours of my face and around my goatee. The shaver can be used wet or dry or with shaving cream. I only ever used it dry, as I had no need to attempt a closer shave, and liked the convenience of a dry shave. Lastly, you can pull off the shaver head and pop on a trimmer head. The downside to this setup is that the trimmer is a separate piece, whereas most shavers have the trimmer integrated into the shaver itself. Cleaning the shaver could not be easier, after each use you simply pull off the top plate of the shaver head and run water through it and the shaver head. When a more intense cleaning is needed you can disassemble the entire shaver assembly and clean out each rotary blade individually with the included brush (I actually throw the blades and heads into the dishwasher on a sanitize cycle to get them extra clean). All in all... a smarty styled shaver that gives a close and comfortable shave. 09/27/2010 Update: I've noticed that even if I don't shave, and let me beard grow for a few days, the shaver still shaves very closely and does not snag on the longer hairs. My old shavers used to snag when I didn't shave every few days.
  701. I've been using a [[ASIN:B000PKKAGO Philips Norelco arcitec 1090 Men's Shaving System]] since December, 2007. I've enjoyed the 1090 and use it regularly whenever I use an electric shaver rather than a blade. This review will serve as a comparison between the two Norelco shavers. Cost: The 1150 is considerably less exepensive without taking any special offers or discounts that may become available into account. Bells and Whistles: The 1090 has more bells and whistles. It has an LED display that shows you how much time is left before recharging is necessary. The 1150 does not. The sideburn trimmer is attached to the 1090. With the 1150 you need to change the shaving head to attach the trimmer. The 1090 is a bit easier to clean. You can just flip up the shaving heads and clean it quite easily. With the 1150 you need to remove the cleaning head off the body of the razor in order to clean it out. It isn't difficult by any means but it does take just a little more time for cleaning. The Shave: My experience has been that the 1150 gives me a much cleaner shave and does so in less time and with less effort than the 1090. This may be due to the curved shaving heads that seems to follow the contours with more efficieny. This is particularly true in those areas underneath the chin and jaw-line. I have to do less stretching and craning of the neck to make sure the shave is completed. Bottom line: For me the lower cost and the more effective shaving experience outweighs the bells and whistles found on the 1090. For those who like the bells and whistles you may prefer the 1090. So if I'm looking to pick one to take on a trip or for when I need a quick shave I'll take the 1150.
  702. The razor itself is pretty basic. It has a nice simple stand and indicator lights to show that the razor is charging / charged, etc. The cutting action isn't superb but sufficient. I used this razor at work for the occasional missed spot or when I have stumbled out of bed. I am not a fan of electric razors because of the cost to benefit ratio, but they have their place. In my drawer at work. I do like that you can pop off the blade and rinse it - just not so sure how this will effect the long term usability of the blade (we all produce oils and dead skin cells that the razor will pick up and lodge into the blades) - I would imagine that some detergent should be used with the blade for more intense cleaning. This will certainly be necessary if you plan to use it everyday. If you want an everyday electric - get a unit with the cleaning unit and spend the money on a more expensive unit.
  703. I've been pretty pleased with this shaver. It's not the top end of the new Philips Norelco line, but it also isn't $300+ and in that regard it provides a very nice counterpoint to today's blade shaving systems. I've dabbled here and there with electrics over the years but have mostly stayed with the disposable-blade system. Yet over the past few years I have become increasingly disenchanted with the cost of the disposable blade systems - every iteration in the disposable razor \\"blades race\\" brings increasing prices of the blades and lessening durability along with the \\"new, 23 blades and shaves your dog too!\\" For me, it's at the point where the cost, year over year, is essentially even or better with this razor. As for the razor itself, it has done a nice job for me - not perfect, but nice. It seems to do a better job with shaving cream (I use a gel), but that may be largely imagined because it glides so much more easily. Philips claims that the best results will be seen after several weeks of regular use - and I'm getting close to that, so we'll see. The higher end shavers might do better with floating heads or multi-pivot as opposed to the two-dimensional pivot of the heads on this razor. It hasn't been a big problem, but I think it is probably holding it back from that truly close shave - or at least from not having to do multiple passes. In these several weeks, I've run the razor on one charge. I have found it to be exceptionally easy to clean - much better than electrics of yore. Plus, I'm a shower shaver and it works just fine in the shower - it is not happy as a purely dry shaver. Overall, I think it is a very solid entry at this price point.
  704. This is an excellent razor. The shave was very close and smooth. It was comfortable and caused no irritation whatsoever. It also fit well in my hand. The razor was the quietest one I've owned, it comes with a 45 day money back guarantee, and on top of all that it has a quick charge. Great product.
  705. This is a decent shaver, but I didn't find the shave itself to be particularly close compared to cheaper electric shavers that I've had: it's about the same. It certainly isn't as close of a shave as a non-electric razor, but of course you wouldn't expect it to be. I've tried it both ways: dry and wet (with shaving cream), and prefer wet but I really didn't notice much of a change in closeness of shave, just a change in overall comfort. I've never been a huge fan of 'flexible' shavers, and it took some getting used to, to achieve the best results. One place where this shaver does not work very well at all, is the neck. Even short neck hairs can be tough to remove with this product. Cleaning is pretty easy, it's easy to open the main attachment, brush with the included cleaning brush and rinse. I'm not a big fan of the charger. Yeah, it looks stylish, and it charges fast if necessary (quick charge feature in a few minutes allows it to be used at full strength for a bit), but it feels unnecessarily cumbersome. I prefer the simple 'plug in' charger on other models. The trimmer does its work great, but you have to remove the main shaver head and insert the trimmer. Not a big deal, but I prefer the convenience of a trimmer included in the shaver itself rather than as a separate attachment. One comparison I can make is with the much lower priced (~$40) 7310 / 7310XL razors also from Norelco. For half the price, you get as good of, if not a better shave from the cheaper product, with almost none of the inconveniences. The trimmer is better for detail work on the 1150x/40, and it looks far more stylish, but in the end that's not worth $60 more to me.
  706. I believe my dad will love it
  707. Excellent buy. High quality. Replaceable head ensures long lasting use. Definitely worth the extra money. Easy to maintain. Only drawback is awkward charging setup.
  708. If you happen to have to shave everyday like most military then this thing is perfect, no more replacing razor blades or forgetting to buy any this is always there. I have fairly sensative skin as well and this doesn't give me razor burn. Easy to clean and care for and one charge lasts about a month or so. Perfect for daily shaving.
  709. It works well, shaves my face well cleans up easily. So far no complaints. We shall see over time how well it stands up to daily use.....
  710. It looks perfect, charged quickly. But when I used it I found this razor a little noisy than expected at this price.
  711. I had to return my razor. What Amazon or norelco don't really tell you is you half to take the head of the razor completely off to attach the mustache trimmer. My advice is DON&#34;T BUY THIS ITEM.

  714. Do not feel very easy to use, yet my old clean shaven, the other is only charging cradle too much trouble
  715. Gave as a christmas gift, not sure of a review at this time. Only used once as of this date.

  718. I'm 25.I like the color and the style.The more important is it's suit me better than the last razor I've used<br /><br />Thanks for the amzon and philips
  719. Good product with reasonable price, there are no reasons not to love it so far! I want to buy it again!
  720. Not using yet, but this is a good price to buy this product, it's a present for farther-in-law. I will add more details a while later.
  721. The razor does pretty well on the sides of my face, but on the chin and neck I have to apply a great deal of pressure. A lot. Sometimes it still leaves a good deal of residual hair behind if I don't check closely. That's never good.<br /><br />Otherwise it handles well. Cleans easily, keeps a charge and doesn't take up a lot of space.<br />Next time will invest a little more money, although for $100 you would think you would get a good shave without too much worry.

  726. I've owned a few razors and the triple head Norelco have worked best for me. They never get as close as a regular bladed razor, but you never cut your self either. It's a trade off I am happy with. I don't use this in the shower, so I can't comment on how waterproof it is, but it looks well sealed. I got a great price so I am very happy. This great price also means that when it comes time to replace the blades the cost of the replacement blades will be substantial compared to the purchase price.<br /><br />08/2013 update - I updated my review by dropping a star. The reason is due to poor design destined to fail, and it did. One of the nice features, which I never used and now never will, is that the shaver is waterproof. The entire front face of the shaver is cover by some sort of plastic. You turn it on and off by pressing a printed logo on the plastic. That means that the plastic has to flex every single time you turn it on and off. Unfortunately the plastic is not up to the task and the plastic cracked. The shaver still turns on and off and works as before, but since the plastic cracked it is no longer waterproof. In fact is worse because now the circuit board is exposed. I can see the crack continuing to open up till the plastic fails all around the switch. That will eventually leave a huge hole. It's too bad as this was otherwise a good shaver.
  727. not a lowest parice to buy it,but i love it,it's bravo.--a chinese buyer
  728. I'm not very happy with this razor. It doesn't work very well unless you use the cream that comes with it. Even then it takes longer to shave than with my old (much cheaper) razor. What is even worse is that the shaving gel goop builds up inside of the razor head so you have to spend about 5-7 minutes extra to clean it after each use! What a time waster. The shave itself is pretty smooth but only if you use the cream.

  730. I have used Norelco for years and felt it was time for a new razor. This razor shaves good but not as well as I was hoping - I guess I over sold by the commercials. All that said I feel the razor is worth the cost. I would recommend it.
  731. The Phillips Norelco 1150X/40 gives a smooth and comfortable shave. I had an older Norelco that finally quit. This is the first on I have bought in 15 years and It is lighter and easier to use than my old one. I would recommend this to all my friends.
  732. I have a young teenager who was starting to look a bit scruffy until I purchased this razor from Phillips Norelco for him. After months of unsatisfactory shaving with a safety razor, I've heard nothing but praise from him about this new razor. And he looks better too!! :)

  740. i am not a big fan of electric razors so when i had a chance to review this, i thought i would try them again. wow, norelco really came through. i used this in the shower, on my legs and it gave a perfect shave. it's easy to hold, even when soapy. you can use this with or without shaving cream. it has a pivoting head and glided over my knees and ankles perfectly. i also had my hubby try it on his face and he really hate electric shavers more than i do. he says they never get his neck area smooth. well, he tried this and even he was surprised at the close shave. he especially liked it because he can use it in the shower, which is where he does shave. it got his neck smooth, smoother than any other shaver he has tried. he uses disposable and he says he still likes that the best but he said if he had to buy any shaver, this one would be it. he is a marine and very particular about his appearance. i personally love this and it seems like they really improved the electric shave. it's convient and quiet and gives a smooth shave. i love it and will continue to use it on my legs. great product !
  741. I'm very impressed by the Philips-Norelco after a week of usage. Note, I'm not the hirsute type, and I usually use a Gillette Fusion every 1.5 days or so. With the Norelco, I get a shave that's even closer than that of the Fusion, and can last me 3 days before shaving. The primary downside of the Philips-Norelco is that shaving takes about 3x as long as with my Fusion razor. I experienced some razor burn upon initial usage, but after the third or fourth time, the 1150X felt very comfortable. OVERALL DESIGN: The recharging station/stand is a slim cradle with a small footprint, which easily fits in any bathroom. I liked the addition of 3 miniature suction cups at the bottom of the cradle, and they provided surprisingly good grip without requiring much depression of the cradle. The cradle comprises two electrodes which connect to the shaver on the sides. The rechargeable battery here is a much-appreciated Lithium-Ion, which can hold a full charge for 40 minutes of continuous shaving, or about a dozen overall shaves. The 1150X shaver itself is sleek and comfortable to hold. It fits my smaller hands perfectly, and has 4 buttons on the body, comprising a main power on/off, travel lock indicator, battery low indicator, and charging indicator. The 1150X was supposed to come with a travel pouch, but it was nowhere to be seen. However, since it comes with a travel lock, a travel pouch isn't terribly critical. The shaving unit has 3 circular blades mounted on a head that can pivot, tilt inwards, and flex outwards. The system is described as \\"2D\\", but I'm not sure how it differs from the more expensive \\"3D\\" models. This 2D 1150X appears to be able to perform all the mobile functions of the more expensive models. OPERATION: Flick on the power switch, and you're ready to go. I find I really need to stretch my skin to get a good close shave. It takes a bit longer to shave than a straight razor as previously mentioned, but the shave is very close. I usuallywet shave, by applying the usual shaving cream, and running the shaving unit under the faucet. The 1150X also comes with a trimming accessory for trimming sideburns and beards, but I found the trimmer to be completely useless. I resorted to my Gillette Fusion to shave my sideburns more efficiently and speedily. There was initially some razor burn, but this quickly subsided by the time I used it a third and fourth time. CLEANING: Just a quick word about cleaning; it's very easy to perform here. Just pop the top of the shaving unit off, and run it under the faucet. A cleaning brush is provided. Since this is an entry-level model, it does not come with the jet clean system, but a quick run under the faucet is more than sufficient to clean the 1150X, unless you're Chewbacca. PROS: - Close shave - Comfortable grip - Long battery charge - Li ion rechargeable batteries - Compact design and small footprint base cradle - Easy to clean CONS: - Shaving takes longer - Trimmer useless - No travel pouch Since the 1150X is the entry-level model of the SensoTouch line of shavers, I was curious as to what features are missing from the 1150X as compared to the higher end models. The 1150X is missing a replace shaving heads indicator, cleaning indicator, and full numeric battery level indicator. The paint jobs on the more expensive models are also glitzier, with a larger usage of chrome. The more expensive models also include a larger capacity battery with shaving time up to 1 hour on a full charge, and a standby duration of up to 20 days. Lastly, the more expensive models supposedly have a better cutting mechanism, and a jet clean washing system for automatically cleaning the shaver. Overall, I'm very happy with the 1150X.
  742. Received this shaver yesterday, and had a chance to play around with it. It is very ergonomic, easy to hold. None of my other electrics have ever done well on my neck, yet this 1150x has no problem. The head does a wonderful job of adapting to your face to get as many hairs as possible; you can even use it in the shower! The shaver gets 5 stars. However, to plug it in, you must dock it in the cradle. This may make it hard to travel with, although this is somewhat mitigated by a 40min battery. It also doesn't come with a case. One other qualm is the trimmer. The head of the shaver pops out and can be replaced with a trimmer instead of the trimmer being on the back of the unit. This however does make it a bit easier to use the trimmer, since the unit is so easy to hold. I love this shaver so much I am contemplating getting another for travelling. You won't be disappointed with this shaver, and if you are, Norelco offers a 45 day guarantee.
  743. This is my first battery powered razor. I do not have beard, have only light mustache which I shave everyday. I just charged the razor once, been using it for 3 weeks, and still works good. I am very happy with this razor.
  744. Buy the Sensor Touch 3D instead.

I wish I could afford the Senso Touch 3D since it has a few more extra features, but this is a great alternative at this price. I gave this product 5 stars for what it is. Yes, the $299 model is amazing, but for the price and the results, this razor is a 5 star in my book.

The only negative is that you cannot use the shaver when plugged in, which can be inconvenient if you forgot to charge the shaver.   765. I have been using a cheapy $30 model for a couple years. It tears my face up and leaves it itchy and red. But could just never bring myself to pay hundreds for something better. Then I finally decided I had to because I got to where I put off shaving for as long as possible. I narrowed down my choice to the Philips 2D and 3D. I'm sure the 3D is all sorts of amazing, but I'm not super obsessed with getting the most super close shave possible. The 2D is terrific, it's smooth, and it doesn't leave my face/neck irritated. Glad I didn't waste the extra $100 for the 3D. I still have to go over some spots a few times to get every last hair, but nowhere near like my cheapy model. And really the only reason I'm taking off a star is because this one is a little harder to get right under my nose. Something about the design of the heads I guess. A little more effort there gets it done, though. Very pleased with my purchase.

  773. I have one of these razors. Although not purchased here, I am submitting this review because I am a frequent Amazon customer.<br /><br />After less than 6 months of use, a part of the drive mechanism in the lower half of the head fell off in the sink when I took the cutters off to wash then. The part was a small triangular piece that is pressed on to a drive shaft that spins the cutters. It does not appear to be repairable, and the entire head would need to be replaced - probably more expensive than it is worth.<br /><br />Although a Norelco user for decades, I'm switching to a Remington foil design. The Norelco triple head razors just don't seem to be built as well as they used to be.
  774. I've been using Norelco electric shavers since around the time that I started shaving, close to 40 years ago. I've gone through a progression of Norelco models. They've always been well made and usually last for many years. Eventually, the battery begins to lose charging capacity or a new \\"must-have\\" feature is introduced that compels me to buy a new one. My most recent shaver, an 8140XL, was still going strong after years, but it wasn't shaving quite as well, probably because of worn blades. I was weighing the option of buying replacement foils and blades (and expensive proposition) or going for a new model. The SensoTouch 2D models looked interesting and were not outrageously priced like some of the newer 3D 1200-series models. But, I was sceptical that they would do a dramatically better job than my existing shaver. I've never had good results with shaving around my neck. I'd always end up with some stubble and missed spots. I guess that I learned to live with it. On my first use of the 1150X, I was amazed with how well it followed the neck contours and it really did a noticeably better job of getting the chin and neck stubble off. After three weeks of ownership, I've been very impressed. These really are the best shaving results that I've ever encountered with an electric shaver. I do have some concerns. The attachment point from the shaving head to the body looks like it could have some mechanical stability problems. I do note one recent review which mentions that this piece broke after 6 months of use. I hope that that experience was an outlier. I'm also annoyed that the new design requires one to use the charging stand when charging the shaver. In the past, you could plug the charging cable directly into the shaver. This new design is awkward for travel. If I'm gone for more than a week, I really would feel compelled to take the charging stand and AC adapter. The stand looks like it could get crushed and break in my luggage. This was a poor design choice, though I suspect that Norelco went in this direction to enable the shaver to withstand water when cleaning. Those concerns aside, I'd recommend this series of SensoTouch 2D shavers.
  775. It is a very nice razor,I mean I like it since I receive the package.Original (MADE IN NETHRELANDS)product,higher quality than its cheaper models which from China.It is a gift to my friend,I do not use it,so I do not know if it works fine.However it looks nice

It provides a closer shave in less time (less passes). Andit holds charge better (aided by less time shaving). That said, it's not so good as to be revolutionary or anything.
