  787. ive always gone with norelco electric shavers for their quality. My last one lasted 4 years and still worked when i bought this one! I keep my head shaved everyday, and this shaver is so good that you can get a very close shave for even your head. I'm very happy i upgraded to this one after having the last 1 for 4 years.   794. This is my first electric razor and I am very happy with it. I did quite a bit of research into electric razors before I bought this and that has definitely paid off.<br /><br />Moving from a traditional razor to an electric has a adjustment time which has been extensively written about on the web. It took me around a week to get a good shave and a couple of weeks before I was totally satisfied. As the product documentation says, try to use it on every shave instead of switching back to your old razor in between. It is fairly quiet and smooth to use. One of my favorite things about the razor is how long the charge lasts - I shave daily and one full charge lasts me around 3-4 weeks. This is great because I don't need to carry the charging stand etc. on my travels. Cleaning is easy (I don't have the jet clean system) - just take the razor head off and place the blades under running hot water for about 30 secs.<br /><br />Overall a great purchase.
  795. This gets close to the skin and leaves a good clean look. It does not get as close as a razor but is great for use in between.

  806. Let me start out and say; what a pile of junk. I have an old Remington 3 Head rotary. it wasn't the most expensive model, but it was good and I had no issues with it. Unfortunately the internal batteries no longer would hold a charge and it time for a new one. I did my research and thought the Philips Norelco 1150X/40 SensoTouch 2D Electric Razor was going to be the one. Man was I mistaken. I'm use to a rotary head shaver and this one is sad. It doesn't have anywhere near the cutting capability; leaving a lot of hair unshaven on my face. I also noticed that the foil heads had nowhere near the same number of holes as my old shaver. I shaved one side with this new one and shaved the other with my crappy Remington and the Remington gave me a closer shave. The blades on the Remington are 6 months old too<br /><br />The things I disliked about it:<br />1. The floating head arrangement is cheesy and doesn't float as well as other rotary shaver I've had. They way they pivot really does not contour to you face. It's a limited \\"2D\\" shaver.<br />2. I had to go over my face multiple times to get the same shave I did only once with the old shaver<br />3. You need the base if you're traveling because it's the only way to charge it.<br />4. The charge indicators don't tell you when it's fully charged and kinda hokey.<br />5. Noisey and felt under-powered.<br />6. The trimmer is a separate attachment and it's pitiful<br /><br />I really had high hopes for this and it totally let me down. Look for something else to shave with.<br /><br />***Update: 02/16/14 - I ended up with the Philips Norelco AT830 Powertouch with Aquatec Electric Razor and what a difference. It works well on my face and actually gave me a closer shave. The trimmer is built in and it's quiet. Been using it for a week and very impressed so far with no negatives. Feels better built and more solid then the flimsy 1150.

  817. I've been shaving for about 20 years, and using an electric razor the whole time. I've shaved with a blade maybe 10 times in my life. This is the fifth electric shaver I've owned, and all have been Norelco. The most recent shaver I had before the 1150x was a Norelco 8140XL which I bought close to five years ago. I've replaced the blades before, and the blades were getting dull again. I decided that due to the age, the battery was probably going to go out sooner or later, so rather than pay $30 for new blades, I'd invest in a new shaver. I selected the 1150x and I've had it for about 3 weeks. I'm definitely getting a smoother shave with the new shaver, but I think that's probably due to the new blade rather than the shaver itself. The 1150x does a better job on my neck than the 8140XL. The \\"SensoTouch 2D\\" means the blades push in and out and flex to the contours of your face better. However, I think the 8140XL did a better job on my upper lip. But generally I'd say it's about the same overall. I think the closeness of the shave is about the same, too - maybe the 1150x slightly closer, but again I'd bet that is due to the new blade and not the shaver. Some other reviews mentioned the amount of counter space the shaver takes up. In comparison to the 8140XL, it's roughly the same amount of space. The 1150x is more difficult to clean. With the 8140XL, you just pop the top which is on a hinge, empty any excess hair into the wastebasket, rinse the whole thing under warm water, and close it back. The 1150x has a detachable head, and then you have to separate the blades from that and rinse two pieces that are separate from the shaver itself. Still not that hard, but more troublesome than the 8140XL. I generally shave in the morning and leave the shaver in the charger after I finish shaving until the next morning, so never have trouble with charging. However, I did notice that while it's charging it makes a faint high-pitched hum. It's not loud at all and I didn't even notice it until the fourth day I had it. The hum goes away when it's not charging (if you remove it from the charger, or after it finishes charging). Never had a hum with the 8140XL. Generally I think this is a good shaver, but I think I liked the 8140XL better.
  818. Purchased this shaver for my husband as a Christmas gift and he loves it! Stunning appearence as the picture shown on web and my hubby said it's handy and smoothy when shaving although i will never have a chance to try:). Also good Amazon delivery service, they deliver the item on time with DHL so that i can always track my package online. Happy online shopping exp, good service and good shaver, recommand!

  832. I got this on Amazon for $50 on sale.   833. I've really liked, and used, Braun shavers for decades, but this Norelco shaver is my new standard. Braun foil systems worked well for me, but, as I have gotten older and my facial hair has gotten more random in its orientation and curvature, problems developed. I'd been having issues with too many hairs that got missed by my shaver. My solution had been to use the trimmer on my shaver to cut these longer hairs and/or to shave with a blade to get them. I bought the Norelco shaver thinking I would use it instead of the blade every few days to get those longer hairs. Instead, the 1150x/40 shaved me so well and so comfortably that it has replaced my Braun shaver for everyday use. It doesn't shave as close as a blade, but it does shave as close, and as comfortably, as a Braun and it cuts all the hairs.
  834. After using this razor for six months, my initial impressions were confirmed--it's flimsy, cheaply made, and doesn't shave very well--with or without shaving cream. It is mostly definitely not worth its premium price. As someone who doesn't grow much of a beard (asian!), it's a little absurd that I have to pass this thing over my face and chin 7-10 times to cut the few hairs on my face off--even then, it's obviously not as close as a cheap-o disposable razor. The blade-head is also pretty abusive to skin--maybe I'm extra sensitive--but I'm starting to get acne when I didn't before. Shaving creams/gels just makes the Norelco experience worse/messier. The sideburn trimmer is of even worse quality--it rips hairs rather than trims them. My recommendation is to NOT buy this razor. I'm definitely going back to my regular three blade pharmacy razor. If you really want an electric razor, stay away from this one--get a decent quality cheaper one or go elsewhere! Making a terrible razor worse, I bought this with the idea of getting a rebate. I got a note saying they didn't get my UPC code--but what can I do? I can't send another UPC if I already sent it. If they lost it, I can't magically make a new one. Letters and phone calls--to no avail. So, I have a terrible expensive razor with no rebate.
  835. My 10 year old Norelco Advantage Wet/Dry razor finally broke, so it was time to get a new razor. I tried a Braun, but realized I missed the ability to use shaving cream to reduce razor burn. In addition, I am used to and now prefer to be able to shave in a circular motion to catch my hairs from all angles. The 1140x works fairly well in this regard, but I wish I had my old razor back. This razor is similar to my old one in closeness of shave and because I can't use it if I wait more than a day between shaves. However, the new razor has clipped the skin at the corners of my mouth a couple of times and left me bleeding - ouch! In addition, I travel a lot and you can't charge this razor without the stand (The AC cord plugs into the stand only) which is annoying. In addition, this razor doesn't come with a travel case. Thankfully, I can use the neoprene case that came with my old razor.

  848. There are many good reviews for this shaver. I bought one after reading them.   849. The Philips Norelco SensoTouch electric shaver is very nicely designed and constructed. It shaves closely<br /><br />The design on the SensoTouch is quite futuristic, with a blue front, curved body, and perched shave head. It fits comfortably in the hand, and has a rubber ridge that runs around the edge for added grip (especially useful when using the shaver wet). The shaver has only one button on it, the power button, which is flush with the front of the shaver face. On the shaver front are also three indicator lights. They display low battery, battery charging, and control lock status. The control lock lets you disable the power button to prevent it from accidentally turning on (when traveling for instance). One annoying aspect of the shaver's design,<br /><br />Shaving with the SensoTouch is kind of odd at first. The shaver puts very little pressure on your face. At first I didn't think I was pushing hard enough to get a close shave, but it was shaving just as close as any other electric shaver I've ever used. Indeed, you can push as hard as you like, but it never feels like you're pushing down hard. I've learned to use the SensoTouch with a light touch, and the payoff is a close shave with less irritation. The shaver head pivots smoothly in all directions, and the three shaving heads pivot individually as well. The shaver screens have holes for shorts hairs and slots for longer hairs. Indeed, I had no problem getting a close shave on the contours of my face and around my goatee. The shaver can be used wet or dry or with shaving cream. I only ever used it dry, as I had no need to attempt a closer shave, and liked the convenience of a dry shave. Lastly, you can pull off the shaver head and pop on a trimmer head. The downside to this setup is that the trimmer is a separate piece, whereas most shavers have the trimmer integrated into the shaver itself.<br /><br />Cleaning the shaver be easier, after each use you simply pull off the top plate of the shaver head and run water through it and the shaver head. When a more intense cleaning is needed you can disassemble the entire shaver assembly and clean out each rotary blade individually with the included brush<br /><br />All in all... a smarty styled shaver that gives a close and comfortable shave.haver head. When a more intense cleaning is needed you can disassemble the entire shaver assembly and clean out each rotary blade individually with the included brush All in all... a smarty styled shaver that gives a close and comfortable shave.
  850. Given the fact that I'm only in my early twenties, I don't have that much shaving experience. However, I have been using electric shavers since I started shaving as a teenager (first a Remington, then a low-end Norelco, then the Norelco 1150X), and I am confident that the 1150X is the best one I've used-and I've only been using it for 3 weeks! The shave is very close and can even get the hairs on my neck that other shavers have been unable to eliminate. Plus, I got this shaver for just $20 (I didn't buy from Amazon, but got a $30 gift card at the store where I did buy it-Wal Mart-plus Norelco is offering a $30 mail in rebate for all Senso Touch shavers). UPDATE (Feb. 20, 2012): So it turns out that the mail-in-rebate is invalid if your purchase came with ANY other discounts, even if they aren't traditional discounts (in my case, I got a Wal-Mart gift card), something which is not explicitly stated on the rebate form. The shaver still works great, but I've now lowered the rating to one star to reflect my displeasure with Philips' business practices. I will NEVER give Phillips my business again!

  897. I just found out that this itme they offered back in December 2011 with a $30 coupon and a $30 rebate from Phillips was null and voided as told to me by a phillips representative, They being Phillips are not accepting any rebates for the $30 they offered because they state when you accept the $20 or $30 coupon offered by amazon you are attempting to combine offers which is not allowed under phillips policy basically stating you cannot stack your coupon with a rebate to get $60 bucks off the item, now amazon did not state anything at the time i purchased the item that you couldnt use the rebate after accepting their coupon upon purchasing the item but now phillips is not accepting my rebate, so yes i good deal on the price of the item at the time of purchase but the item should have been discounted $60 bucks total as AMAZON was offering it, but because myself and several other customers naturally used their coupon and submitted the rebate we screwed ourselves out of $30 and amazon i believe knew that phillips would not honor those rebates in the first place because the form clearly states you cannot combine deals, so BUYER BEWARE if amazon is offering a coupon without a rebate by all means take advantage of the item, but if there is a rebate attached to the item as well, make sure its says you can stack both before using both you basically have to choose 1 or the other for most items and specially for phillips/norelco items, after calling and giving them a good piece of my mind for what i believe is false advertising on amazon's and phillips part they are sending me a 15% off coupon for future purchases, so again buyer beware...dont get burned like myself and im sure several thousand other people who purchased this item in dec 2011...<br />0
  898. This is the first electric shaver I've owned so take it with that context.<br /><br />I think this product works somewhat well, but as my title implies, it's hard to get a very close shave. For cutting long hairs, it's great. It's very fast and leaves no irritation at all. But for the \\"20%\\" of smaller hairs, it takes a very long time to get a smooth shave with this. For now, I use this for about 20 seconds in the morning and then switch to a 5-blade cartridge razor to clean up the rest. I'd say it improves my shaving experience, but certainly doesn't replace my old razors.

  904. With razor. But it is not the most suitable for Asian. But the price, but you are not satisfied with it?
  905. I've used this SensoTouch shaver for over three months now and am generally very happy with it. It offers a hassle-free, idiot-proof shave. Although the shave doesn't feel quite as close as my old Braun Series 5,the difference is negligible, and the SensoTouch wins in terms of comfort, ease, and cost.<br /><br />THE SHAVE<br />---<br />Effectiveness: I have a very angular face with a slow-growing, thin beard. This SensoTouch is very effective for my face and beard type. The slight arch outwards in the head design means I can shave my chin areas easily, which is something I found hard to do with the Braun. The large head means that it's harder for me to miss an errant, bit of stubble. As long as I use the circular-pressing motion they recommend in the manual, I get no irritation. Shaving the neck is a non-issue.<br /><br />Comfort: The SensoTouch offers a comfortable shave. The body of the shaver feels solid in the hand and is swooped to ensure that it won't slip. The circular-pressing motion you're asked to do gets a bit tiring at first, my wrist started feeling strange near the end of my second shave, but it's not a problem any more. Because the head is large, you won't have to do many circular motions to cover your face. I found it helpful to slightly pull-tight my skin as the shaver went over the area. Either way, this shaver has never cut me, unlike the Braun, which gave me various scars as I learnt to use it.<br /><br />Result: On the first pass for me, it cuts fairly close. Although it's smooth to the eye, it's not smooth to the touch. At this point, I'll dump out the collected hairs, and then do another pass. At the end of the second round, I'm smooth to the touch and will generally not need to shave until two days later. I like to follow up with [[ASIN:B003ZH74F4 Genuine Ogallala Bay Rum Aftershave]], but it's not by any means essential. With my Braun, assuming I didn't miss any areas, I could go about three days without a shave.<br /><br />THE PRODUCT<br />---<br />Build: The SensoTouch is well built and feels solid. Not as hefty as the Braun, but it doesn't need to rely on weight to give a good shave. Unfortunately, the charging station is a T-style cradle that is made of the cheapest, lightest plastic in the world. This makes it difficult to quickly drop the shaver in. The cradle will fall or skid away. After the shaver's in, it's own weight makes things much more stable, though. As well, in order to hook the charging cable to the cradle, you really need to jam it into the port. For a long time, I was wondering why the charging cable would keep on getting disconnected.<br /><br />Battery Life: I took this shaver on holiday for a week using it for a total of at least 30 minutes without recharging it. The thing worked fine, with no loss of motor torque or any other oddities.<br /><br />Value: Compared with the Braun, the Sensotouch is a great value. Besides the rotor heads, which really should take years to wear out, there isn't much that could go wrong. No expensive foils or assemblies to replace. Other than the charging dock and cord, I can see the SensoTouch lasting for years. At a below-double-digit price, it's probably the best shaver you'll get for an angular face.
  906. Bought it last Nov while there was a $30 rebate promotion in addition to a $30 up-front discount (so the final price should be ~$20). However, as you've probably seen from other reviewers, the $30 rebate got rejected. Talked to their customer support and they said it's the same promotion and can't used twice. Trust me, like many of you guys, I read all the fine prints really carefully. Nowhere it said they were the same discount. It's really disappointing!<br /><br />In terms of the product, it's just a $20 product with a bit more fancier design.

Just stay away from Philips and you'll be much happier in the end.<br /><br />Amazon on the other hand stepped up as always, took up the issue on themselves and issued me a $30 credit without an hassle.<br />Maybe Philips should look into things like \\"customer retention\\" \\"customer loyalty\\" \\"customer service\\" into their business model. Learn from Amazon!!!

  910. Very comfortable razor, that does a decent job, it just seems supremely under powered. I had to go over everything multiple times to get a clean shave, and I don't have a heavy beard.   911. I bought the Norelco Shaver from Amazon at the end of the year last year and got a great price on it. Because of the great price, I thought that the shaver would have some issues but I was very pleased with the shaver once I received it. This shaver is definitely the best shaver I have owed, by far. This shaver shaves incredible close and the battery lasts forever.<br /><br />Up until I bought the Phillips shaver, I was using an electric shaver to shave a couple times a week and then would do a close shave with a razor Blase once a week, too to get the hard to cut and thin hairs that the razor didn't catch. That process is a thing of the past now that I have this shaver. The Phillip does a nice clean shave every time and doesn't leave any hair behind. I can't say enough about how close it shaves.<br /><br />As far as holding a charge, the Phillips is amazing. This is going to sound like I am exaggerating but for me, shaving twice a week, the charge lasts somewhere over 12 weeks. I have literally charged this shaver three to four times since I have owned it. Totally amazing battery life.<br /><br />There was one very big issue, though, and a limitation of this type of shaver / the company. This type of shaver, with three heads, doesn't allow you to shave right under your nose well, especially if your are shaving around a mustache, as I need to. It's just to hard to get one of the heads in there with out risking shaving parts of your mustache, you are not trying to shave. Phillips does give you an attachment for such reasons but for me swapping shaver heads every time I shave is a bit messy so I use a trimmer for such purposes. This problem is more an over all three head shaver problem and not a Phillips problem so I didn't knock any stars off for the problem.<br /><br />I liked this shaver so much that I bought one for my father for Xmas. This is where the my real issue is. The one I bought for my father was at the same amazing price but also was supposeto give a $30 rebate back. A month after submitting the paper work, I got a notice back from Phillips saying that they don't do dual offers (I'm paraphrasing). I am not allowed to get the discount price and a rebate. This is really not fair and a little shady since the rebate time frame corresponded with the discount. Nowhere in the rebate paper work did it say that I could receive a discount and a rebate. Reading the Amazon forum on this, I can see that this happened to many other people.<br /><br />The shaver itself is 5 star shaver but I rate the company 3 stars so I am giving an overall 4 star rating.
  912. Let's be honest...the best shave you can get is from a professional barber..with hot towels and hot foam...after that it's trial and error because of different hair and skin types...I shave my head and face and the barber is a treat at $25-$30 low end..it last 2-3 days<br />I usually use Mach 3 or above on head and face..which can be long, messy, and I always have a cut or two..the price of refills is skyrocketing and I decided to try this..<br />I ordered it thurs..got it sat!...I first tried the 1150 dry,and I was surprised that with several days growth..I was able to get a reasonably close shave..no cuts or mess...I then washed my face thoroughly, applied shave gel and could not believe it..as close if not closer than the blades...my wife checked for places I usually miss and I hadn't ...and without a scratch..<br />I usually don't review items however when you feel you have gotten what you've paid for(for a change)why not ..<br /><br />Also seems by some of the reviews that people want a pro shave at home??.   921. I have a plug-in Philips Norelco razor that I've used for over ten years. I think the blades finally were getting dull because it seemed like I wasn't getting the shave I used to get. I looked at the different models of the cordless Norelco shavers, I finally decided that spending big bucks on a fancy razor was not money well spent. I'm very glad I went with this model- it gives me a very close shave (better than the old one when it was new) and is comfortable to use. The trimmer being an extra piece is not a problem, and it does a much better job than the pop up one from the old razor. I was concerned that the charge life being shorter with this model might be a disadvantage, but I've been going on the first charge for over a month. Two-D versus three-D capability? My face doesn't know it's been short changed. It does run quieter than I expected, the impression is that it isn't as strong but in fact it does quite well.<br /><br /> Down sides: I don't like the way the head comes apart for cleaning, you can't get a good grip on it because it feels like you could easily damage the cutting foils, and that it could go flying out of the hand when it snaps loose. This razor doesn't do as good a job at capturing longer hairs as my old one did (although the old electric was capable of taking a nip out of my lip if I got too close); if I have skipped a couple of days (gone camping) it really has difficulty making a clean sweep of my face. If I've got the light good and bright and spot some whiskers that didn't get clipped, I'll run around and over and back and forth and seem not to make any progress. Also, I question the recommendation to rinse the shaving head under water because I've heard the tap water will cause the blades to dull prematurely unless they're scrupulously dried (and who's got time for that?). Maybe the jet clean system offered on the other models is worth the money, but I really didn't want an appliance on my bathroom counter. I cleaned theold one manually for many years, It's not that big a deal.<br /><br />Bottom line- it's a pretty good razor for the money and I'm glad I bought it.<br /><br />Edit: I was not sure if the reputed longer battery life of the more expensive models was important, but I took a chance on this. I've been waiting on the low battery light to come on . . . . 42 days of shaving and today it finally flickered on! I don't know how many minutes on average I use it every day, but I shave thoroughly and use the trimmer often. No complaints on this score.
  922. This mid range shaver is great! I like the flexible heads, ergonomic, and water resistant design. The replacement heads are easy to find and my local store has plenty of them.<br /><br />Having this shaver is a no brainier that wont break the bank. Battery lasts long enough to leave the charger at home while weekend/business traveling, but is also 110/220 great when leaving the states.

Not a big issue as I don't use the trimmer much but it could get annoying for those who do.
  926. Bottom-Line: On balance I am very disappointed in the SensoTouch 1150x Electric Shaver, so the search continues to replace my Advantage 7735X.<br /><br />Life sucks sometimes!! After years of use my trusty Norelco Advantage 7735X final gave up the ghost! The head of the razor came apart, springs and all, and I had no choice but to toss the whole thing into the garbage.<br /><br />Now over the years I have tried a number of razors--any number of traditional one-to-four blade straight (disposable) handles, as well as electric units from Remington and Norelco. All of them irritate my skin to some degree and leave razor bumps (Black men are more susceptible to razor bumps than white men because of the course curly nature of our hair). Traditional razors tend to irritate my skin the most, and through experimentation over the years, I have found that Norelco brand razors tend to irritate my skin much less than all the others. So, I have stuck with Norelco for the past fifteen years or so.<br /><br />So when my Norelco Advantage 7735X broke I was forced to find a comparable replacement, only to discover that Norelco no longer makes the 7700 series of lotion dispensing electric razors. I like the lotion dispenser because it lubricates the skin while I shave and at the end of the process abrogates the need for aftershave lotion.<br /><br />What I ended up purchasing was the Norelco SensoTouch 1150x Electric Shaver. Since I shave my head and face at least three times a week, it is important to me that any razor I use shave closely without, again, irritating my skin. After several days of use I can report that I am very disappointed in the SensoTouch 1150x Electric Shavers' performance; after I shave my scalp is often dry and somewhat flaky in need of lotion. However, there are no shaving bumps so that is a great outcome, but there is a considerable amount of stubble left behind, shaving wet (in the shower) or dry.<br /><br />Unlike the Advantage 7735X, which ships with 5 lotion packs by Nivea that are easy to insert into the back of the razor, the SensoTouch 1150x Electric Shaver does not come so equipped. And that for me is the main disadvantage of the razor; while the Advantage 7735X shaves closely, without lotion, and even better with it, without some sort of moisturizer the SensoTouch 1150x Electric Shaver fails to shave as closely as I'd like.<br /><br />You can also use shaving cream with the SensoTouch 1150x Electric Shaver, but that can get a bit messy (I only tried it once) and the shave was not much better and the reason I use an electric razor is so I do not have to use shaving gel!<br /><br />I like the design of the unit, it is cutting edge and stylish. The razor fits easily into the hand and while running the SensoTouch 1150x Electric Shaver is quieter than the unit it replaces, the motor is underpowered and I could actually hear the blades slowing down if I pressed the razor to closely to the skin.<br /><br />The SensoTouch 1150x Electric Shaver is cordless and comes with a charging stand that can automatically switch to the prevailing voltage, so traveling overseas will not be an issue. But there is no carrying case.<br /><br />I have owned three other Norelco razors, and the only one that shaves as close as the Advantage 7735X was the Advantage 5655. On balance I am very disappointed in the SensoTouch 1150x Electric Shaver, so much so that I returned in to Amazon.com where I purchased it for $79.97. So the search continues...5 lotion packs by Nivea that are easy to insert into the back of the razor, the SensoTouch 1150x Electric Shaver does not come so equipped. And that for me is the main disadvantage of the razor; while the Advantage 7735X shaves closely, without lotion, and even better with it, without some sort of moisturizer the SensoTouch 1150x Electric Shaver fails to shave as closely as I'd like.<br /><br />You can also use shaving cream with the SensoTouch 1150x Electric Shaver, but that can get a bit messy (I only tried it once) and the shave was not much better and the reason I use an electric razor is so I do not have to use shaving gel!<br /><br />I like the design of the unit, it is cutting edge and stylish. The razor fits easily into the hand and while running the SensoTouch 1150x Electric Shaver is quieter than the unit it replaces, the motor is underpowered and I could actually hear the blades slowing down if I pressed the razor to closely to the skin.<br /><br />The SensoTouch 1150x Electric Shaver is cordless and comes with a charging stand that can automatically switch to the prevailing voltage, so traveling overseas will not be an issue. But there is no carrying case.<br /><br />I have owned three other Norelco razors, and the only one that shaves as close as the Advantage 7735X was the Advantage 5655. On balance I am very disappointed in the SensoTouch 1150x Electric Shaver, so much so that I returned in to Amazon.com where I purchased it for $79.97. So the search continues...

  948. The Philips Norelco 1150x40 SensoTouch 2D electric razor performs quite well on stubborn hairs! This can be used 'wet or dry' and is very sturdy and easy to clean. It has a good long battery life, too. I would recommend this over a more expensive brand-- cuz it does the job!
  949. First off, let me say that I have thick stubble that is somewhat thin (as opposed to dense) on my face. The first few shaves were spotty and left many random stragglers, but after about 5 days of shaving daily, I began getting the best shave I've ever gotten with a DRY electric. Also, I have had minimal irritation while using this razor. After a couple months, I started getting lax on it and stopped shaving everyday since my beard grows pretty slowly and now am suffering. It seems that when I go even 2 days without shaving, it's like starting over, irritation and kind of bad shave again. I've always had trouble with longer hairs missing, and my beard grows pretty flat against the skin, so this is likely my issue. However, this has really helped my shaving, since I hate to do it, and manual shaving I would routinely go a week or more between shaves. I've tried wet shaving with cream a few times, and it was awesome, but what's the point of that? If I'm going to use cream I'll use a manual razor too!
  950. I think some people can be a little quick to complain sometime with items and also don't understand that unfortunately you do run into the occasional defected item which is sometimes why people seem to lose their minds and post a terrible review which often discourages people. With that said, I purchased this item in December of 2010. I have to say that I've owned one other shaver (Foil) that shaved much faster BUT irritated my face very much. This shaver doesn't irritate me at all. This seems to be more of a \\"take your time\\" kind of shaver but it will get the job done with very little to no missed spots. If there is, go over it a few times and the hairs are gone. It's a pretty close shave as well...very close to a razor except this doesn't irritate my face like a razor. The battery holds a GREAT charge. It is VERY easy to take apart and clean. Read the directions on how to take it apart rather than doing it wrong and breaking it which results in you giving a unwarranted bad review. Shaves great dry or wet (i prefer a wet shave with shaving gel...much smoother). For the price compared to some others, there is good value....and with the current $30 coupon I'd jump on this quick. I don't think you'll regret it. I didn't, I love this shaver.
  951. After about 10+ years, I finally had to replace m old Norelco electric shaver and replaced it with the 2d 1150/40 SensoTouch 2d. The price on Amazon, was a good price with free s/h. I got the 2d mixed up with the 3d and other higher (and more expensive) models in this line and couldn't take advantage of the $10 manufacturer rebate. In any case, this is the best working shaver I've owned and I have no regrets buying it, even though the run time on the battery charge is lower than other SensoTouch models. I probably have light growing facial hair but the the first charge lasted me an entire month before the battery charge warning light started to blink. So, I have no issues on how long the battery charge lasts. As for the shave itself, this shaver gives me the best shaves day after day. After reading someone's else review on not needing the SensoTouch that comes bundled with the head cleaner device, I opt'd to just get the shaver and no cleaner device. Now and then, all I do is pop the 3-head shaver head off exposing the rotary blades and I just rinse the blade holder part and the base under hot water as instructed. After, I take a tissue to pat dry and everything is ready to go again. Very easy. Excellent electric shaver. This base model SensoTouch was worth buying. You can buy the higher level models and pay the higher prices but I don't think you will get a better shave, just more bells and whistles.
  952. ------ Introduction ------ I've no idea why, but apparently it is generally believed that someone with naturally coarse, curly hair (i.e a Black man) should never invest in a rotary or foil electric razor because they don't work on that type of person's face. While clinging to this notion, Blacks have the choice of contending with those relentless razor bumps produced by manual razors (the propensity of our hair to curl facilitates this) or turning to messy harsh, depilatory cremes/powders that produce offensive odors. ---- I was tired of bumps, messes, and nonsense, so I invested in this shaver(the Norelco 1150x). The bottom line: My first shave was brilliant despite the fact that my face hasn't even adjusted to a rotary blade Norelco has a sort of money-back guarantee deal in the event that it doesn't do the job for you, so there's no reason not to be confident in the machine's ability to dominate your facial hairs. I opted to wet shave and was a bit hasty about it, missing a few hairs on my cheek, but it seems every bit as close as manual shave. With a manual blade, shaving without missing the patch of hairs adjacent to the trachea and on my chin without cutting myself was a challenge. Depilatories would remove some hair, but not nearly all of them, and require me to wait 36 hours before trying again without damaging already tingling skin. The Norelco got the job done with no irritation. Aesthetically, this machine stands out from the other mid-range rotaries and foils. In person, it is not as vibrant blue as it appears online, and that's good. With the charger, it does not take up much space. I was thankful it did not come with the massive Jet Clean charger/cleaner system. The trimmer is a neat bonus.
  953. I have had the shaver for a few months now, it took a while to get used to but so far its gone a month without the charge light coming on. The shave isnt quite as close as you would get with a manual razor but its much better and quicker than any electric razor I have used before.
  954. I have no idea if this is as good as electric razors get or not but I splurged on this thinking that this would work great, but it does not. It says on the instruction that to go in circular motion and I did and it still does not shave well. You have to like totally get this is the right spot and sweet spot on your face. your neck and chin, fogetttaboutit!!! I have to move this thing around my face up, down, in, out, every angle possible before i get a complete shave. BTW, I am not a hairy person at all. I normally shave 2-3 times per week.

  968. I have used Norelco electric shavers basically since I started shaving. They are very easy to use and much more economical than disposable razors and their expensive refills. I have always found the round tri-head electric shavers from Norelco work much better than the foil syle design from Remington and others. I think they really do shave just as well as a blade. This shaver is no exception. It looks cool to begin with but the most important thing is that it works very well. This thing is so light (almost too light in that it feels slightly less sturdy than older designs) and it glides across your face even without using pre-shave or shaving cream (yes it will work with cream!). It is super quiet when using. It comes with a nice charging base and clearly indicates on the shaver itself when it is charging and turns off when completed. It charges fast as well. The only 2 negatives I have with this product are: 1) The charging base has suction cups to help hold it in place but they are sort of small. We have Corian style solid surface sink tops in our bathroom and the suction cups don't want to stick to it very well so it sort of slides around and makes it hard to keep in one place. It can tend to tip over as well when the suction cups don't hold. 2) This unit is entirely cordless and ONLY works as a cordless shaver. Meaning, you can't plug the cord directly into the unit and use it as a corded shaver. Why is this important do you ask when you are buying a cordless unit for the convenience of being cordless? As I said, I've used Norelco shavers for a long time. After a while the batteries will stop accepting a charge and they are not easily replaced. When this happens (like it did with my last older style) I could still shave and just needed to use the cord. With this unit once the batteries start to die it is basically time to get a new one. Since I got this for only $50 with a $30 off coupon at Christmas that is not too big of a deal but it is a minor inconvenience. All in all though this shaver is very nice and does a great job, especially since it is the bottom of the line model! I'm not sure how the higher models could do much better.

  1038. I went out and purchased this at a local store for about $100 bucks. I am working overseas in a location that does not suit the typical razor and cream, so I thought I would try this out. After about a month I can honestly say that I am not very impressed. It takes forever to shave with this thing. If you happen to wait a week in between shaving just forget about using this shaver. It will do the job eventually, but misses long strands of hair on the face and neck. You will have to continuously go back and try and get the stragglers. Since I found this out, I have been using it every other day with somewhat adequate results. Using this shaver on your neck is a pain in the butt. It does not just glide over your face and neck. The directions say use a swirling pattern. Last time I tried that I cut the side of my lip and portions of my neck... I have only used this as a dry shaver, so no info on the cream or wet shave. The shaver is relatively easy to clean and charge. The little beard trimmer attachment is garbage. My 10 dollar beard trimmer does a better job. I gave this shaver three out of four because it does work (with a little effort) and is somewhat cheaper than the other models.

I am disappointed as neither Amazon nor Philips warn about this trap. I certainly would not have purchased this if I knew I would not receive the full discount. Most discouragingly, I am currently chatting with a representative from Philips simply named \\"Mack\\". He has been very abrupt with me, not answering questions really only giving me the same line.   1046. Unfortunately we could not honor your request due to the following reason: Manufacturer's discounts taken at the cash register are not valid for rebate promotions.\\"<br /><br />That reason never showing on their rebate form.   1047. Norelco doesn't honor its rebates. It rejected the rebate applications of everyone who purchased this product from Amazon at a discount. The postcard we all received said \\"Manufacturer's discounts taken at the register are not eligible for rebates.\\" However, the rebate form states, \\"Offer is not redeemable in stores.\\" So the rebate couldn't have been taken at the register. Upon calling them, I was given a different reason, that the rebate form said, \\"May not be combined with other offers.\\" Clearly, that meant that you cannot use two rebates from Norelco on the same item, not that you cannot receive a discount from the seller and still be eligible for a rebate. It's disgusting that a company as large as Philips would try to dodge its obligations on a flimsy pretext like that. I will never buy another product of theirs and I urge anyone reading this not to either. I hope it costs them a lot more than the amount they saved on all of the $30 rebates they by improperly rejected.

  1062. I had been using a foil shaver that finally gave out on me. I decided to go back to a rotary type to replace it. While I was waiting to get the new Norelco I dug out a 10 year old Remington Titanium shaver that I had stopped using. It still worked well when plugged into the AC. The batteries were about gone which was not surprising considering its age. When I got the Norelco in and started using it I was sadly disappointed at how much less closely it shaved me over the 10 year old Remington. It also had more drag across my face than the Rem due to all the rubber surrounding the cutting heads. I also discovered that you cannot plug an AC power cord into it to keep it going in case you forget and let it run down. You can with the Rem. I returned this Norelco and ordered a new Remington R5130xlp (about the same price). It shaves much closer and with less drag on my face. Better ergos in my opinion as well, but that is subjective. I also prefer its mechanical on/off switch and a % of charge remaining lights that this Norelco does not have.

  1069. I'm a big fan of this shaver in terms of how well it works and its battery life, but one area where it really falls short is its travel-friendliness. What makes this such a pain to travel with is the charger: it is a rigid stand about 3/5ths the height of the shaver, and while it has suction cups on the bottom of it that give it the ability to stick to mirrors and some surfaces, the stand is bulky and EXTREMELY awkward to carry anywhere. And even if you are able to fit in a travel bag or another part of your suitcase, you have to worry about it breaking it - thus eliminating your ability to charge your shaver.<br /><br />PROS:<br />+ sleek, modern look<br />+ good battery life<br />+ very flexible and surprisingly soft shaver head (good for nice close shave resulting in smooth skin afterwards)<br />+ nice and intuitive indicator lights (telling you if the battery is low, if the device is charging properly, etc.)<br />+ seems to be very water resistant<br />+ comes with shaver, beard trimmer, charging stand (with cord), and cleaning brush<br /><br />CONS:<br />- charging stand is rigid, bulky, and VERY difficult to travel with<br />- shaving attachments sometimes fall off when shaving (the happens quite seldom and the chance of it can be minimized by making sure that you apply a good amount of pressure when inserting the shaving attachments)<br /><br />Hopefully Phillips Norelco can develop a way to make the travel stand foldable so that it will be much easier to travel with because that would make this product an easy 5-star device.

  1075. fit meSpeaking of, the shaver charges somewhat unconventionally. It has a base that you drop it into and it charges through contacts on the side of the shaver. A complete charge takes 1 hour, and lasts 40 minutes. The low battery light alerts you when there are 5 minutes of shave time left. The only disadvantage to this system is that you cannot use the shaver while it is plugged in. If you're like me and put off charging till the last minute, you may find yourself out of juice when you need to shave in a hurry. A quick charge feature allows you to charge the shaver for 5 minutes, and get 3 minutes of shaving time, but sometimes 5 minutes is more than I have when I'm in a rush.

  1106. I have used a Norelco triple head shaver for the last 20 years, had many units and replaced the cutters and I was still happy with the product. I bought this one last year (January 2012) from Amazon as a present for myself, since it looked like a neat design and had features which I liked. The charging stand is an added bonus. So what's the problem, you say? It just does not remove the hairs from those hard to shave places, like under my nose, along the sides under the shin and even under my lower lip. The old Norelco units I had did not have the amount of give that the new ones do in the motion of the cutting heads. So, now it sits in a drawer and I finally had enough of complaints from my inspector general wife that she could still see the hairs after a shave. Solution: I researched shavers and found the Panasonic ES-LA63-S Nanotech 4-Blade (Arc 4) Multi-Flex Dual-Motor Electric Shaver and ordered it from Amazon last month. Now this is a real improvement. Removes all the hair from the hard to shave areas and it passes the Wife Test. I won't be using my Norelco since I have found a shaver that really works and meets all my needs. Sorry Norelco/Amazon, but time moves on and so have I. Moral: never change a design that has worked for many years just to sucker in some new shavers in the youth crowd who don't know better. If you are one of the newbies, be my guest, but you owe to yourself to try the Panasonic line.

  1160. Summary: This shaver gives an inferior shave, but it has some great features that might make it a good choice for those with a light beard or who don't care about a close shave.<br /><br />Pros:<br />- Great ergonomics - fits well in the hand and a nice light weight.<br />- Handy charging cradle makes it easy to recharge (compared to tight cord plug on other shavers).<br />- Does a good job of shaving the jawline and neck.<br />- Cool blue color and smooth, soft-touch design.<br />- Not really quiet but a better timbre than other shavers makes it seem quieter.<br />- The charge seems to last a really long time.<br />Cons:<br />- A bit more irritating than the competition.<br />- Not a close shave.<br />- Five o'clock shadow makes appearance around noon.<br />- Tough to shave the upper lip.<br />- No incremental charge indicator.<br />- Seems to be a slower shave than the competition.<br /><br />Full Review: Shaving is a pain in the neck, but I do it daily. I always shave wet (usually in the shower) and I use a good, non-foaming gel (King of Shaves). I say shaving dry with an electric razor is only slightly better than shaving dry with a blade. I've been using Panasonic shavers for about five years now after liberating myself from the overpriced Fusion system. Loved the Panasonics, but decided to try the Philips Norelco 1150X/40 based on positive reviews I read here. The thing I've found really annoying about the Panasonic razors is that the batteries fail to hold charge after about two years. My current Panasonic shaver (my 2nd) has a bad cell, so the indicator goes from 60 to zero in about 30 seconds. This means I need to remember charge every third day. I saw where Norelco offered a 2.5 year warranty so figured I'd give them a try. I liked the look and feel of the shaver. But, well.... the shaving not so much. I used the slick blue shaver for three weeks - it took about a week for my beard to adjust - and the results were just okay. My daughter called me &#34;Mr. Scratchy&#34; - really, the closeness that I've achieved with the comparably priced Panasonic mid-level razor was no contest. The Panasonic has more difficulty getting a clean shave on some parts of the neck and has a more annoying buzzing sound, but with a shave that is so superior I can only recommend this razor for perhaps 15 year-olds with only a few whiskers or others who have light beards.Scratchy&#34; - really, the closeness that I've achieved with the comparably priced Panasonic mid-level razor was no contest. The Panasonic has more difficulty getting a clean shave on some parts of the neck and has a more annoying buzzing sound, but with a shave that is so superior I can only recommend this razor for perhaps 15 year-olds with only a few whiskers or others who have light beards.
  1161. Dissapointed in the quality of the shave. Not sure if blades need replacing...probably as with most products in todays world. You buy the product and spend tons on upkeep (printer cartridges come to mind)
  1162. I have been using Norelco electric razors 25 years or more, I decided to try the new format unit. It works adequately and the battery last for many shaves,
  1163. very good The design on the SensoTouch is quite futuristic, with a blue front, curved body, and perched shave head. It fits comfortably in the hand, and has a rubber ridge that runs around the edge for added grip (especially useful when using the shaver wet). The shaver has only one button on it, the power button, which is flush with the front of the shaver face. On the shaver front are also three indicator lights. They display low battery, battery charging, and control lock status. The control lock lets you disable the power button to prevent it from accidentally turning on (when traveling for instance). One annoying aspect of the shaver's design, however, is that it is close to impossible to lay the shaver down without it turning on its side, and then dumping out some shavings onto the counter. You just have to remember to place the shaver back in the charging base if you have to stop mid-shave.
  1164. I like it ! It gives you a great shave! long lasting battery life without recharging it- easy to clean! great price!
  1165. This shaver is lighter and easier to hold and maneuver than the previous model I've used for 10 years. It doesn't have the triple blades but doesn't need them: it is fast and close. You can't beat the price and it's well worth it. I almost did not get it but I'm so glad I did. It has space-age looks and would do the job for anyone: a great shave in half the time.

  1173. I recently purchased this shaver at Target and returned it. I have used Braun shavers for many years (at least since 1988). My most recent Braun shaver's battery would no longer hold a long enough charge and it was time for a replacement. I visited my local Target and fell in love with the look of this razor and the fact that replacement blades were much cheaper than Braun's. I decided to give this Norelco a try. I found that I got a very close shave, but the razor was very time consuming to keep clean, if you followed Norelco's suggested cleaning methods. About 3 weeks after purchase I noticed that the plastic body was opening at the seams on both sides of the body and returned it to Target the next day. I asked the clerk if this was unusual and he said he had seen this at least 1 time before. I replaced it with a more a expensive Braun Series 5 shaver and could not be happier with it. Sorry I was unfaithful.

This product can also be used in the shower which is convenient if you like a wet shave. Two drawbacks, trimmer is not the best and in order to use it you have to detach the shaving head.   1232. I have tried Remington, Panasonic and other Norelco brand shavers over the years. All of them would work ok, but I would have to shave my neck/face twice weekly with a blade because the shaver just couldn't get to certain spots. This shaver takes care of neck hair and fine facial hairs that my other shavers missed. The flex head design works very well fitting facial and neck contours and leaves a close shave. I haven't used a blade and shaving creme for weeks. The only downfall is the trimmer head is separate from the shaver (not built in) and one must remove the rotary heads and snap on the trimmer head if you want to use it. I kept my old Panasonic shaver and use its trimmer when needed (it is built in to the shaver) and do not bother with the swap out. Otherwise, I love this shaver. Great price on Amazon and Norelco had a coupon for $20 off around Christmas, so paid about $55 for the best shaver I have ever owned. My wife loves the close shave and I would definitely buy this shaver again!

  1246. i decided to buy this shaver when it went on sale a few months ago. Being a longtime Braun user I hesitated, but the price was too good to pass. unfortunately, I now remember why i stopped using the norelco shavers. My overall feeling is that the unit does an ok job. I decided to try it as a wet shaver, using a foamy soap, a high quality shaving cream, and also dry. I am not too happy with results. I noticed much more irritation than I'm used to, especially on dry. Granted, I've been using the Braun singlefoil style shaver for a very long time, and I suspect that matters. But more importantly, i think the irritation comes from having to do way more passes than I normally would, especially shaving my chin and neck. Unfortunately, it just can't seem to be able to shave those areas without a lot of work and consequently irritation. I had less irritation when using soap or shaving cream, but that's probably because i did less passes; that also meant it didn't actually shave those areas very well and there was always stubble.<br /><br />would i buy again? probably not. I dont' really have much of a beard,so I'd hate to see someone with a thick beard trying to work this thing. I will continue to use it, but not for long. I will probably just get another Braun.
